message.content: <passage><t0>I</t0></passage>

<passage><t1>Mr. Jones, owner of Manor Farm, closed the henhouses for the night, but he was too drunk to remember that he had left the windows open.</t1> <t2>With the light of the lantern dancing from side to side, he crossed the yard, took off his boots at the back door, poured himself a final glass of beer from the barrel in the kitchen, and went straight to bed, where Mrs. Jones was already snoring.</t2></passage>

<passage><t3>As soon as the light went out in the bedroom, the commotion began throughout the farm.</t3> <t4>During the day, word had spread that Old Major, the prize boar, had had a strange dream the previous night and wanted to share it with the other animals.</t4> <t5>They had agreed to all meet in the main barn once Mr. Jones retired.</t5> <t6>Old Major (that was always his name, although he had been exhibited under the name Willingdon Beauty) was so highly regarded on the farm that everyone was willing to lose an hour of sleep to hear what he had to say.</t6></passage>

<passage>
    <t7>At one end of the main barn, on a sort of raised platform, Major was already settled comfortably in his straw bed, under a lantern hanging from a beam.</t7> 
    <t8>He was twelve years old and had recently become quite fat, but he was still a majestic pig with a wise and good-natured appearance, despite his tusks never having been cut.</t8> 
    <t9>After a short while, the other animals began to arrive and settle down comfortably, each in their own way.</t9> 
    <t10>First came the three dogs, Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher, and then the pigs, who settled down in the straw in front of the platform.</t10> 
    <t11>The hens perched on the windowsills, the pigeons fluttered up to the rafters, the sheep and cows lay down behind the pigs and began to chew the cud.</t11> 
    <t12>The two cart-horses, Boxer and Clover, entered together, walking slowly and placing their large hairy hooves with great care, fearing that some small animal might be hidden in the straw.</t12> 
    <t13>Clover was a sturdy mare, getting on in years and with a maternal appearance, who had not managed to regain her figure after her fourth foal.</t13> 
    <t14>Boxer was an enormous beast, nearly eighteen hands high and as strong as two ordinary horses put together.</t14> 
    <t15>A white stripe down his nose gave him a somewhat stupid appearance, and indeed he was not very intelligent, but he was respected by all for his steadiness of character and tremendous powers of work.</t15> 
    <t16>After the horses came Muriel, the white goat, and Benjamin, the donkey.</t16> 
    <t17>Benjamin was the oldest and the worst-tempered animal on the farm.</t17> 
    <t18>He rarely spoke, and when he did, it was usually to make some cynical remark; for example, he would say that "God had given him a tail to keep the flies off, but that he would rather have had no tail and no flies."</t18> 
    <t19>He was the only animal on the farm that never laughed.</t19> 
    <t20>If asked why, he would say that he saw nothing to laugh at.</t20> 
    <t21>However, without openly admitting it, he was devoted to Boxer; the two of them usually spent their Sundays together in the small paddock beyond the orchard, grazing side by side without speaking.</t21>
</passage>

<passage><t22>As soon as the two horses lay down, a group of ducklings that had lost their mother entered the barn, chirping weakly and wandering from side to side in search of a place where they wouldn't be in danger of being stepped on.</t22> <t23>Clover formed a sort of wall with her enormous front hoof, and the ducklings nestled there, falling asleep immediately.</t23> <t24>At the last moment, Mollie, the pretty and silly white mare that pulled Mr. Jones's cart, entered affectedly, chewing on a sugar lump.</t24> <t25>She positioned herself in front, flirting with her white mane to draw attention to the red ribbons with which it had been braided.</t25> <t26>The last to appear was the cat, who, as usual, sought the warmest place, finally settling between Boxer and Clover; there she purred contentedly during Major's speech, without hearing a single word of what he was saying.</t26></passage>

<passage><t27>All the animals were already present —except for Moses, the tame raven, who was sleeping on a perch behind the back door—.</t27> <t28>When Major saw that they were all settled and waiting attentively, he cleared his throat and began:</t28></passage>

<passage><t29>—Comrades: you have already heard about the strange dream I had last night.</t29> <t30>But I will talk about that later.</t30> <t31>First, I have to say something else.</t31> <t32>I do not believe, comrades, that I will be with you for many more months, and before I die, I feel it is my duty to pass on to you the wisdom I have acquired.</t32> <t33>I have lived many years, had plenty of time to meditate while I have been alone in my sty, and I believe I can say that I understand the meaning of life in this world as well as any other living animal.</t33> <t34>It is about this that I wish to speak to you.</t34></passage>

<passage><t35>"Let's see, comrades: What is the reality of this life of ours?</t35> <t36>Let's face it: our lives are sad, laborious, and short.</t36> <t37>We are born, we are given the necessary food to sustain ourselves, and those of us who are able to work are forced to do so until the last ounce of our strength; and the very moment we are no longer useful, we are killed with appalling cruelty.</t37> <t38>No animal in England knows the meaning of happiness or leisure after reaching one year of age.</t38> <t39>There is no free animal in England.</t39> <t40>The life of an animal is only misery and slavery; this is the plain truth.</t40></passage>

<passage><t41>"But, does this really form part of the order of nature?"</t41> <t42>"Is it perhaps because this land of ours is so poor that it cannot provide a decent life for all its inhabitants?"</t42> <t43>"No, comrades; a thousand times no."</t43> <t44>"The soil of England is fertile, its climate is good, it is capable of providing abundant food for a much larger number of animals than currently inhabit it."</t44> <t45>"Our farm alone can support a dozen horses, twenty cows, hundreds of sheep; and all of them living with a comfort and dignity that at this moment is almost beyond our imagination."</t45> <t46>"Why, then, do we continue in this miserable condition?"</t46> <t47>"Because human beings take away almost all the fruit of our labor."</t47> <t48>"There it is, comrades, the answer to all our problems."</t48> <t49>"Everything is explained in a single word: Man."</t49> <t50>"Man is the only real enemy we have."</t50> <t51>"Remove man from the scene and the root cause of our hunger and overwork will be abolished forever."</t51></passage>

<passage><t52>»Man is the only creature that consumes without producing.</t52> <t53>He does not give milk, he does not lay eggs, he is too weak to pull the plow, and his speed does not even allow him to catch rabbits.</t53> <t54>Yet he is lord and master of all the animals.</t54> <t55>He makes them work, gives them the bare minimum to keep them alive, and keeps the rest for himself.</t55> <t56>Our labor tills the soil, our manure fertilizes it, and yet there is not one of us that owns more than his skin.</t56> <t57>You, cows, who are here, how many thousands of liters of milk have you given this last year?</t57> <t58>And what has become of that milk which should have been used to raise sturdy calves?</t58> <t59>Every last drop has gone down the throats of our enemies.</t59> <t60>And you, hens, how many eggs have you laid this year and how many chicks have hatched from those eggs?</t60> <t61>All the rest has gone to the market to produce money for Jones and his people.</t61> <t62>And you, Clover, where are those four foals you bore, that should have been the support and joy of your old age?</t62> <t63>All were sold at a year old; you will never see them again.</t63> <t64>As a reward for your four offspring and all your work in the fields, what have you had except for your meager rations and a stall?</t64></passage>

<passage><t65>"They don't even allow us to reach the natural end of our miserable lives."</t65> <t66>"I don't complain for myself, because I have been one of the fortunate ones."</t66> <t67>"I am twelve years old and I have had more than four hundred offspring."</t67> <t68>"Such is the natural fate of a pig."</t68> <t69>"But in the end, no animal escapes the cruel knife."</t69> <t70>"You, young pigs sitting in front of me, each one of you will be squealing for your life within a year."</t70> <t71>"We will all come to that horror: cows, pigs, chickens, sheep; all of us."</t71> <t72>"Not even the horses and dogs have a better fate."</t72> <t73>"You, Boxer, the very day your great muscles lose their strength, Jones will sell you to the knacker, who will cut your throat and boil you down for the hunting dogs."</t73> <t74>"As for the dogs, when they are old and toothless, Jones ties a brick around their neck and drowns them in the nearest pond."</t74></passage>

<passage><t75>Isn't it then of the utmost clarity, comrades, that all the evils of our lives stem from the tyranny of human beings?</t75> <t76>Eliminate Man, and the product of our labor will belong to us.</t76> <t77>Almost overnight, we would become rich and free.</t77> <t78>So, what must we do?</t78> <t79>Work night and day, with body and soul, to overthrow the human race!</t79> <t80>That is my message, comrades: Rebellion!</t80> <t81>I do not know when that rebellion will come; perhaps in a week or in a hundred years; but I do know, as surely as I see this straw beneath my feet, that sooner or later justice will be done.</t81> <t82>Keep your eyes fixed on that, comrades, during the few years you have left to live!</t82> <t83>And, above all, pass on my message to those who come after, so that future generations may continue the struggle until victory is achieved.</t83></passage>

<passage><t84>"And remember, comrades: your will must never waver.</t84> <t85>No argument should sway you.</t85> <t86>Never pay attention when they tell you that Man and animals have common interests, that the prosperity of one is also that of the others.</t86> <t87>They are lies.</t87> <t88>Man serves the interests of no being except his own.</t88> <t89>And among us animals, let there be perfect unity, perfect comradeship in the struggle.</t89> <t90>All men are enemies.</t90> <t91>All animals are comrades.</t91></passage>

<passage><t92>At that moment, a tremendous commotion occurred.</t92> <t93>While Major was speaking, four large rats had come out of their hiding places and had sat on their haunches, listening to him.</t93> <t94>The dogs suddenly spotted them and only by a swift dash to their refuges did the rats manage to save their lives.</t94> <t95>Major raised his paw to impose silence.</t95></passage>

<passage><t96>—Comrades —he said—, there is a point here that must be clarified.</t96> <t97>Wild animals, like mice and rabbits, are they our friends or our enemies?</t97> <t98>Let's put it to a vote.</t98></passage>
<passage><t99>"I pose this question to the assembly: Are the rats comrades?"</t99></passage>

<passage><t100>It was put to a vote immediately, and it was decided by an overwhelming majority that the rats were comrades.</t100> <t101>There were only four dissenters: the three dogs and the cat, who, as was later discovered, had voted on both sides.</t101> <t102>Major continued:</t102></passage>

<passage><t103>—I have little left to tell you.</t103> <t104>I simply insist: always remember your duty of enmity towards Man and his ways.</t104> <t105>Anything that walks on two legs is an enemy.</t105> <t106>Anything that walks on four legs, or has wings, is a friend.</t106> <t107>And also remember that in the struggle against Man, we must not come to resemble him.</t107> <t108>Even when you have defeated him, do not adopt his vices.</t108> <t109>No animal must live in a house, sleep in a bed, wear clothes, drink alcohol, smoke tobacco, handle money, or engage in trade.</t109> <t110>All the habits of Man are evil.</t110> <t111>And, above all things, no animal must tyrannize over his own kind.</t111> <t112>Weak or strong, clever or simple, we are all brothers.</t112> <t113>No animal must kill another animal.</t113> <t114>All animals are equal.</t114></passage>

<passage><t115>"And now, comrades, I will tell you about my dream from last night."</t115> <t116>"I am not in a position to describe it to you."</t116> <t117>"It was a vision of how the earth will be when Man has been outlawed."</t117> <t118>"But it brought to my memory something that I had long forgotten."</t118> <t119>"Many years ago, when I was a little piglet, my mother and the other sows used to sing an old song of which they only knew the tune and the first three words."</t119> <t120>"I learned that song in my childhood, but I had long since forgotten it."</t120> <t121>"Last night, however, it came back to me in the dream."</t121> <t122>"And more than that, the words of the song as well; words that, I am certain, were sung by animals of long ago and then forgotten for many generations."</t122> <t123>"I will sing that song to you now, comrades."</t123> <t124>"I am old and my voice is hoarse, but when I have taught you the tune you will be able to sing it better than I can."</t124> <t125>"It is called 'Beasts of England.'"</t125></passage>

<passage><t126>The old Major cleared his throat and began to sing.</t126> <t127>Just as he had said, his voice was hoarse, but despite everything, he did quite well; it was a rhythmic tune, something halfway between "Clementine" and "La Cucaracha."</t127> <t128>The lyrics went like this:</t128></passage>
<passage><t129>Beasts of England, beasts of Ireland! Beasts of every land and clime!</t129></passage>
<passage><t130>Hear my joyous news that sing of a happy future!</t130></passage>
<passage><t131>Sooner or later the time will come</t131></passage>
<passage><t132>in which the tyranny of Man is overthrown and the fertile pastures of England</t132></passage>
<passage><t133>only by animals are they trampled.</t133></passage>

<passage><t134>From our snouts, the rings will be banished, from our backs, the harnesses will disappear.</t134> <t135>Bits and spurs will fall prey to rust and never again will cruel whips crack.</t135> <t136>Richer than the mind could imagine, wheat, barley, oats, hay, clover, alfalfa, and beetroot will be ours alone on the appointed day.</t136> <t137>The meadows of England will shine radiantly and purer waters will flow; gentler will the breeze blow on the day our freedom shines.</t137> <t138>For that day we must all work even if we must die without seeing it.</t138> <t139>Horses and cows, geese and turkeys, all must unite and fight for freedom!</t139> <t140>Beasts of England, beasts of Ireland! Beasts of every land and climate!</t140></passage>
<passage><t141>Hear my joyous news that sing of a happy future!</t141></passage>

<passage><t142>The rehearsal of this song put all the animals in the wildest excitement.</t142> <t143>Shortly before Major had finished, they had all started singing it.</t143> <t144>Even the most stupid had retained the melody and part of the lyrics, while the more intelligent ones, like the pigs and the dogs, learned the song in a few minutes.</t144> <t145>Shortly afterwards, with the help of several previous rehearsals, the entire farm broke into singing "Beasts of England" in unison.</t145> <t146>The cows mooed it, the dogs howled it, the sheep bleated it, the horses neighed it, the ducks quacked it.</t146> <t147>They were so pleased with the song that they repeated it five times in a row and would have continued all night if they hadn't been interrupted.</t147></passage>

<passage><t148>Unfortunately, the armed commotion woke up Mr. Jones, who jumped out of bed believing there was a fox prowling around the pens.</t148> <t149>He took the shotgun, which was permanently in a corner of the bedroom, and fired a shot into the darkness.</t149> <t150>The pellets embedded themselves in the barn wall and the meeting broke up hastily.</t150> <t151>Everyone fled to their sleeping places.</t151> <t152>The birds jumped onto their perches, the animals lay down in the straw, and in an instant, the whole farm was asleep.</t152></passage>
<passage><t153>II</t153></passage>
<passage><t154>THREE nights later, Old Major died peacefully in his sleep.</t154> <t155>His body was buried at the foot of the orchard.</t155></passage>

<passage><t156>That happened in early March.</t156> <t157>During the following three months, there was a great deal of secret activity.</t157> <t158>To the most intelligent animals on the farm, Major's speech had made them see life from a completely new perspective.</t158> <t159>They did not know when the Rebellion that Major had predicted would occur; they had no reason to believe it would happen during their own lifetimes, but they clearly saw that their duty was to prepare for it.</t159> <t160>The work of teaching and organizing the others naturally fell upon the pigs, who were generally recognized as the most intelligent of the animals.</t160></passage>

<passage><t161>Prominent among them were two young pigs named Snowball and Napoleon, whom Mr. Jones was raising to sell.</t161> <t162>Napoleon was a large, fierce-looking boar, the only Berkshire pig on the farm; he was known for being taciturn and always getting his way.</t162> <t163>Snowball was more lively than Napoleon, had greater ease of speech, and was more inventive, but he was considered to have a weaker character.</t163> <t164>The other male pigs on the farm were very young.</t164> <t165>The best known among them was a small, fat pig named Squealer, with very round cheeks, bright eyes, nimble movements, and a shrill voice.</t165> <t166>He was a brilliant orator, and when discussing a difficult matter, he had a way of skipping from side to side and wagging his tail that made him very persuasive.</t166> <t167>It was said of Squealer that he could turn black into white.</t167></passage>

<passage><t168>These three had developed, based on the teachings of Old Major, a complete system of ideas which they named Animalism.</t168> <t169>Several nights a week, when Mr. Jones was already asleep, they held secret meetings in the barn, during which they explained the principles of Animalism to the others.</t169> <t170>At the beginning, they encountered much stupidity and apathy.</t170> <t171>Some animals spoke of the duty of loyalty towards Mr. Jones, whom they called "Master," or made elementary remarks such as: "Mr. Jones feeds us"; "If he were not here, we would starve to death."</t171> <t172>Others asked questions like: "What do we care about what will happen when we are dead?" or "If the rebellion is going to happen anyway, what difference does it make whether we work for it or not?" and the pigs had great difficulty making them see that this was contrary to the spirit of Animalism.</t172> <t173>The most foolish questions were asked by Mollie, the white mare.</t173> <t174>The first one she directed at Snowball was the following:</t174></passage>
<passage><t175>—Will there be sugar after the rebellion?</t175></passage>

<passage><t176>—No —replied Snowball firmly—.</t176> <t177>We have no means to produce sugar on this farm.</t177> <t178>Besides, you don't need sugar.</t178> <t179>You will have all the oats and hay you need.</t179></passage>
<passage><t180>—And will I be allowed to keep using ribbons in my mane? —insisted Mollie.</t180></passage>
<passage><t181>—Comrade —said Snowball—, those ribbons you like so much are the symbol of slavery.</t181> <t182>Don't you understand that freedom is worth more than those ribbons?</t182></passage>
<passage><t183>Mollie nodded, but it seemed that she was not very convinced.</t183></passage>

<passage><t184>The pigs had an even greater struggle to counteract the lies spread by Moses, the tamed raven.</t184> <t185>Moses, who was Mr. Jones's favorite, was a spy and a gossip, but also a very skilled orator.</t185> <t186>He claimed to know of the existence of a mysterious country called Sugarcandy Mountain, to which all animals went when they died.</t186> <t187>It was located somewhere in the sky, "just a little beyond the clouds," Moses said.</t187> <t188>There it was Sunday seven times a week, clover was in season all year round, and lumps of sugar and linseed cakes grew in the hedges.</t188> <t189>The animals hated Moses because he was a gossip and did no work, but some believed in Sugarcandy Mountain, and the pigs had to argue a lot to persuade them of the nonexistence of such a place.</t189></passage>

<passage><t190>The most loyal disciples were the draft horses Boxer and Clover.</t190> <t191>Both had great difficulty in forming their own judgment, but since they accepted the pigs as teachers, they absorbed everything they were told and conveyed it to the other animals through simple arguments.</t191> <t192>They never missed the secret meetings in the barn and led the singing of "Beasts of England" with which the meetings always ended.</t192></passage>

<passage><t193>The fact was that the rebellion took place much earlier and more easily than they expected.</t193> <t194>In previous years Mr. Jones, despite being a harsh master, had been a capable farmer, but lately he had acquired some vices.</t194> <t195>He had become very discouraged after losing quite a bit of money in a lawsuit, and began to drink more than he should.</t195> <t196>For entire days he would remain in his kitchen chair, reading newspapers, drinking, and occasionally giving Moses crusts of bread soaked in beer.</t196> <t197>His men had become lazy and careless, the fields were full of weeds, the buildings needed repairs, the fences were neglected, and the animals were poorly fed.</t197></passage>

<passage><t198>June arrived and the hay was almost ready to be harvested.</t198> <t199>On the night of Saint John, which was a Saturday, Mr. Jones went to Willingdon and got so drunk at "The Red Lion" that he didn't return to the farm until midday on Sunday.</t199> <t200>The farmhands had milked the cows at dawn and then went off to hunt rabbits, without bothering to feed the animals.</t200> <t201>Upon his return, Mr. Jones immediately fell asleep on the living room sofa, covering his face with the newspaper, so that by nightfall the animals were still unfed.</t201> <t202>Hunger stirred the animals, who could no longer endure it.</t202> <t203>One of the cows broke down the door of the feed store with a butt of her horns, and the animals began to help themselves from the stores.</t203> <t204>At that moment, Mr. Jones woke up.</t204> <t205>Immediately, he and his four farmhands appeared with whips, lashing out in all directions.</t205> <t206>This was more than the hungry animals could bear.</t206> <t207>Unanimously, though nothing had been planned in advance, they pounced on their tormentors.</t207> <t208>Suddenly, Jones and his farmhands found themselves being pushed and kicked from all sides.</t208> <t209>They were losing control of the situation because they had never seen the animals behave in this way.</t209> <t210>That unexpected insurrection of beasts they were used to beating and mistreating at will terrified them almost to the point of losing their minds.</t210> <t211>Soon, they abandoned their attempt at defense and fled.</t211> <t212>A minute later, the five of them were running at full speed down the path that led to the main road with the animals triumphantly chasing them.</t212></passage>

<passage><t213>Mrs. Jones looked out the bedroom window, saw what was happening, hastily put some things in a bag, and slipped away from the farm by another path.</t213> <t214>Moses jumped from his perch and flapped after her, cawing loudly.</t214> <t215>Meanwhile, the animals had chased Jones and his hands to the road and, as soon as they were out, slammed the gate shut behind them.</t215> <t216>And so, almost without realizing what had happened, the rebellion had been triumphantly carried out: Jones was expelled and "Manor Farm" was theirs.</t216></passage>

<passage><t217>During the first few minutes, the animals could hardly believe their victory.</t217> <t218>Their first action was to run all together around the boundaries of the farm, as if to make sure that no human being was hiding within it; then they galloped back to the buildings to erase the last traces of Jones's ominous reign.</t218> <t219>They burst into the harness-room that was at one end of the stable; the bits, the rings, the dog chains, the cruel knives with which Mr. Jones used to castrate the pigs and lambs, all were thrown down the well.</t219> <t220>The reins, the halters, the blinkers, the degrading nosebags were thrown into the fire in the yard, where at that moment the rubbish was burning.</t220> <t221>The whips met the same fate.</t221> <t222>All the animals leaped with joy when they saw the whips burning.</t222> <t223>Snowball also threw into the fire the ribbons that usually adorned the tails and manes of the horses on market days.</t223></passage>
<passage><t224>—The ribbons —he said— should be considered as clothing, which is the distinctive mark of a human being.</t224> <t225>All animals must go naked.</t225></passage>
<passage><t226>When Boxer heard this, he took the little straw hat he used in the summer to keep flies from getting into his ears and threw it into the fire with the rest.</t226></passage>

<passage><t227>In a very short time, the animals had destroyed everything that could remind them of Mr. Jones's rule.</t227> <t228>Then Napoleon led them back to the feed store and served each one a double ration of corn, with two biscuits for each dog.</t228> <t229>Then they sang "Beasts of England" from beginning to end seven times in a row, and after that, they settled down for the night and slept like they had never done before.</t229></passage>

<passage><t230>But they woke up at dawn, as usual, and, suddenly remembering the glorious event, they all went together to the meadow.</t230> <t231>A short distance away, there was a hill from which almost the entire farm could be seen.</t231> <t232>The animals hurried to reach the summit and looked around in the clear morning light.</t232> <t233>Yes, it was theirs; everything they could see was theirs!</t233> <t234>Possessed by this thought, they jumped everywhere, leaping into the air with great jumps of joy.</t234> <t235>They rolled in the dew, bit the sweet summer grass, kicked up clods of black earth, and inhaled its strong aroma.</t235> <t236>Then they made an inspection tour of the entire farm and looked with silent admiration at the plowed land, the hayfield, the orchard, the pond, the grove.</t236> <t237>It was as if they had never seen those things before, and they could hardly believe that everything was theirs.</t237></passage>

<passage><t238>They returned afterward to the farm buildings and, hesitantly, stopped in silence before the door of the house.</t238> <t239>It was theirs too, but they were afraid to enter.</t239> <t240>A moment later, however, Snowball and Napoleon pushed the door with their shoulders and the animals entered in single file, walking with the utmost care for fear of spoiling something.</t240> <t241>They tiptoed from one room to another, afraid to raise their voices, gazing with a kind of reverent awe at the incredible luxury there: the beds with their feather mattresses, the mirrors, the horsehair sofa, the Brussels carpet, the lithograph of Queen Victoria hanging above the mantelpiece in the drawing-room.</t241> <t242>They were coming down the stairs when they realized that Mollie was missing.</t242> <t243>Retracing their steps, they discovered that the mare had stayed in the best bedroom.</t243> <t244>She had taken a piece of blue ribbon from Mrs. Jones's dressing table and, holding it against her shoulder, was admiring herself foolishly in the mirror.</t244> <t245>The others reproached her sharply and went out.</t245> <t246>They took out some hams that were hanging in the kitchen and buried them; the barrel of beer was smashed with a kick from Boxer, and nothing else in the house was touched.</t246> <t247>It was unanimously resolved then and there that the house would be preserved as a museum.</t247> <t248>They all agreed that no animal should ever live there.</t248></passage>
<passage><t249>The animals had breakfast, and then Snowball and Napoleon gathered them all again.</t249></passage>

<passage><t250>—Comrades —said Snowball—, it is half-past six and we have a long day ahead of us.</t250> <t251>Today we must begin the hay harvest.</t251> <t252>But there is another matter we must resolve first.</t252> <t253>The pigs then revealed that, over the past three months, they had learned to read and write using an elementary book that had belonged to Mr. Jones's children and had later been thrown away.</t253> <t254>Napoleon ordered some cans of white and black paint to be brought and took them to the gate that led to the main road.</t254> <t255>Then Snowball (who was the best at writing) took a brush between the two knuckles of his front hoof, crossed out "Manor Farm" from the top rail of the gate, and in its place painted "Animal Farm."</t255> <t256>That was going to be the name of the farm from now on.</t256> <t257>Afterwards, they returned to the buildings, where Snowball and Napoleon ordered a ladder to be brought and placed it against the back wall of the main barn.</t257> <t258>They then explained that, through their studies over the past three months, they had succeeded in reducing the principles of Animalism to seven Commandments.</t258></passage>

<passage><t259>Those seven Commandments would be inscribed on the wall; they would form an unalterable law by which all the animals of "Animal Farm" should henceforth govern themselves.</t259> <t260>With some difficulty (because it is not easy for a pig to maintain balance on a ladder), Snowball climbed up and got to work with the help of Squealer who, a few rungs below, was holding the paint can for him.</t260> <t261>The Commandments were written on the tarred wall in white letters, so large that they could be read from thirty yards away.</t261> <t262>The inscription read as follows:</t262></passage>
<passage><t263>THE SEVEN COMMANDMENTS</t263></passage>
<passage><t264>1.</t264> <t265>Everything that walks on two legs is an enemy.</t265></passage>
<passage><t266>2.</t266> <t267>Everything that walks on four legs, or has wings, is a friend.</t267></passage>
<passage><t268>3.</t268> <t269>No animal shall wear clothes.</t269></passage>
<passage><t270>4.</t270> <t271>No animal shall sleep in a bed.</t271></passage>
<passage><t272>5.</t272> <t273>No animal shall drink alcohol.</t273></passage>
<passage><t274>6.</t274> <t275>No animal shall kill another animal.</t275></passage>
<passage><t276>7.</t276> <t277>All animals are equal.</t277></passage>

<passage><t278>It was written very clearly, and except for where it should have said "friend," it read "imago," and one of the "S" letters was reversed, the wording was correct.</t278> <t279>Snowball read it aloud to the others.</t279> <t280>All the animals nodded in agreement, showing their total approval, and the more intelligent ones immediately began to memorize the Commandments.</t280></passage>

<passage><t281>—Now, comrades —shouted Snowball, throwing away the brush—, to the hayfield!</t281> <t282>Let us impose upon ourselves the honor of finishing the harvest in less time than it took Jones and his men.</t282></passage>

<passage><t283>At that moment, the three cows, which had seemed restless for a while, began to moo very loudly.</t283> <t284>It had been twenty-four hours since they had been milked, and their udders were about to burst.</t284> <t285>After thinking about it for a moment, the pigs ordered some buckets to be brought and milked the cows with reasonable success, as their hooves adapted quite well to the task.</t285> <t286>Quickly, there were five buckets of creamy and frothy milk, which many of the animals looked at with great interest.</t286></passage>
<passage><t287>—What will be done with all that milk? —someone asked.</t287></passage>
<passage><t288>—Jones sometimes used a part of it by mixing it into our food —said one of the hens.</t288></passage>

<passage><t289>—Don't worry about the milk, comrades! —said Napoleon, positioning himself in front of the buckets—.</t289> <t290>That will be sorted out.</t290> <t291>The harvest is more important.</t291> <t292>Comrade Snowball will guide you.</t292> <t293>I will join you in a few minutes.</t293> <t294>Forward, comrades!</t294> <t295>The hay awaits you.</t295></passage>
<passage><t296>The animals went in a rush to the hayfield to start the harvest, and when they returned at dusk, they noticed that the milk had disappeared.</t296></passage>
<passage><t297>III</t297></passage>
<passage><t298>HOW hard they worked and sweated to bring in the hay!</t298> <t299>But their efforts were rewarded, as the harvest turned out even better than they expected.</t299></passage>

<passage><t300>Sometimes the work was hard; the implements had been designed for human beings and not for animals, and it was a great disadvantage that no animal could use the tools that required standing on their hind legs.</t300> <t301>But the pigs were so clever that they found a solution to every problem.</t301> <t302>As for the horses, they knew every inch of the land and, in fact, understood the work of mowing and raking better than Jones and his men.</t302> <t303>The pigs did not really work, but they directed and supervised the others.</t303> <t304>Because of their superior knowledge, it was natural for them to assume command.</t304> <t305>Boxer and Clover would harness themselves to the mower or the rake (in those days, of course, there was no need for brakes or reins) and resolutely marched across the field with a pig walking behind them and saying: "Gee, comrade" or "Haw, comrade," as the case might be.</t305> <t306>And all the animals, even the humblest, worked to toss the hay and pile it up.</t306> <t307>Even the ducks and hens worked, going back and forth all day long in the blazing sun, carrying little bundles of hay in their beaks.</t307> <t308>In the end, they finished the harvest two days less than it usually took Jones and his men.</t308> <t309>Moreover, it was the largest harvest that had ever been seen on the farm.</t309> <t310>There was no waste; the hens and ducks with their keen eyesight had picked up every last stalk.</t310> <t311>And no animal on the farm had stolen so much as a mouthful.</t311></passage>

<passage><t312>Throughout the entire summer, work on the farm went smoothly.</t312> <t313>The animals were as happy as they had never imagined they could be.</t313> <t314>Every bite of food was a delicious treat, as it was truly their own food, produced by them and for them, and not doled out in small portions and grudgingly by a grumpy master.</t314> <t315>Since the useless and parasitic human beings were no longer there, there was more food for everyone.</t315> <t316>They also had more free hours, despite the animals' inexperience.</t316> <t317>Of course, they encountered many difficulties, for example: when they harvested the corn, they had to tread it in the old-fashioned way and remove the waste by blowing, since the farm did not have a threshing machine, but the pigs with their intelligence and Boxer with his powerful muscles always got them out of trouble.</t317> <t318>Everyone admired Boxer.</t318> <t319>He had been a great worker even in Jones's time, but now he resembled three horses rather than one; on certain days it seemed that all the work rested on his strong shoulders.</t319> <t320>He pulled and dragged from morning till night and always where the work was hardest.</t320> <t321>He had agreed with a rooster that it would wake him half an hour earlier than the others, and he would do some voluntary work where it was most needed before starting the normal daily tasks.</t321> <t322>His response to every problem, to every setback, was: "I will work harder!"; it was like a personal refrain.</t322></passage>

<passage><t323>But each one acted according to their ability.</t323> <t324>The hens and ducks, for example, recovered five bushels of corn during the harvest by picking up the lost grains.</t324> <t325>Nobody stole, nobody complained about their ration; the arguments, fights, and envies that were a natural component of daily life in the old days had almost completely disappeared.</t325> <t326>Nobody shirked work, or almost nobody.</t326> <t327>Mollie, in truth, was not very diligent about getting up in the morning, and she had the habit of leaving work early, claiming that a stone had gotten into her hoof.</t327> <t328>And the behavior of the cat was somewhat strange.</t328> <t329>Soon it was noticed that when there was work, she was nowhere to be found.</t329> <t330>She would disappear for entire hours, and then show up at mealtime or at dusk, when the work was over, as if nothing had happened.</t330> <t331>But she always presented such excellent excuses and purred so affectionately that it was impossible to doubt her good intentions.</t331> <t332>Old Benjamin, the donkey, seemed not to have changed since the rebellion.</t332> <t333>He did his work with the same stubbornness and slowness as before, never shirking it and never volunteering for any extra task either.</t333> <t334>He did not give his opinion on the rebellion or its results.</t334> <t335>When asked if he was not happier now that Jones was gone, he would simply answer: "Donkeys live a long time.</t335> <t336>None of you has ever seen a dead donkey."</t336> <t337>And the others had to be content with such a mysterious response.</t337></passage>

<passage><t338>Sundays were not for working.</t338> <t339>Breakfast was taken an hour later than usual, and afterwards, a ceremony took place that was carried out every week without exception.</t339> <t340>First, the flag was raised.</t340> <t341>Snowball had found an old green tablecloth of Mrs. Jones in the harness-room and had painted a hoof and a horn in white on its surface.</t341> <t342>And this emblem was hoisted on the flagpole in the garden every Sunday morning.</t342> <t343>The flag was green, explained Snowball, to represent the green fields of England, while the hoof and the horn signified the future Republic of the Animals, which would arise when they finally overthrew the human race.</t343> <t344>After raising the flag, all the animals would head in a rush to the main barn where a general assembly, known as the Meeting, took place.</t344> <t345>There, the work for the following week was planned, and decisions to be adopted were raised and debated.</t345> <t346>The pigs were the ones who always proposed the resolutions.</t346> <t347>The other animals understood how they should vote, but they never came up with their own ideas.</t347> <t348>Snowball and Napoleon were, without a doubt, the most active in the debates.</t348> <t349>But it was noted that the two of them never agreed; for any suggestion made by one, it could be expected that the other would be against it.</t349> <t350>Even when it was decided to reserve the small field behind the orchard as a retirement home for animals no longer fit to work, there was a stormy debate regarding the retirement age for each class of animal.</t350> <t351>The Meeting always ended with the song "Beasts of England," and the afternoon was devoted to leisure.</t351></passage>

<passage><t352>The pigs made the harness-room their headquarters.</t352> <t353>Every night, they studied blacksmithing, carpentry, and other necessary trades from the books they had brought from the house.</t353> <t354>Snowball also took charge of organizing the others into what he called Animal Committees.</t354> <t355>For this, he was tireless.</t355> <t356>He formed the Egg Production Committee for the hens, the Clean Tails League for the cows, the Committee for the Re-education of Wild Comrades (whose purpose was to domesticate the rats and rabbits), the Whiter Wool Movement for the sheep, and many others, in addition to organizing reading and writing classes.</t356> <t357>In general, these projects turned out to be failures.</t357> <t358>The attempt to domesticate the wild animals, for example, failed almost immediately.</t358> <t359>They continued behaving practically the same as before, and when treated generously, they took advantage of it.</t359> <t360>The cat joined the Re-education Committee and was very active in it for a few days.</t360> <t361>Once, she was seen sitting on the roof chatting with some sparrows that were out of her reach.</t361> <t362>She was telling them that all animals were now comrades and that any sparrow who wished could perch on her paw; but the sparrows preferred to abstain.</t362></passage>

<passage><t363>The reading and writing classes, on the contrary, were very successful.</t363> <t364>By autumn, almost all the animals, to a greater or lesser degree, had some education.</t364> <t365>The pigs already knew how to read and write perfectly.</t365> <t366>The dogs learned to read quite well, but they were only interested in reading the seven commandments.</t366> <t367>Muriel, the goat, read a little better than the dogs, and sometimes, at night, she would read to the others from newspaper clippings she found in the trash.</t367> <t368>Benjamin read as well as any of the pigs, but he never exercised his abilities.</t368> <t369>As far as he knew, he said, there was nothing worth reading.</t369> <t370>Clover learned the entire alphabet, but she couldn't form the words.</t370> <t371>Boxer couldn't get past the letter D. He could trace A, B, C, D in the dirt with his enormous hoof, and then he would stand staring at the letters with his ears back, sometimes moving his mane, trying to remember what came next, but never succeeding.</t371> <t372>On several occasions, it's true, he managed to learn E, F, G, H, but when he did, he found that he had forgotten A, B, C, and D.</t372> <t373>Finally, he decided to settle for these four letters, and he would write them once or twice a day to refresh his memory.</t373> <t374>Mollie refused to learn more than the six letters that made up her name.</t374> <t375>She would form them very neatly with pieces of branches, and then she would decorate them with a flower or two and walk around them admiring them.</t375></passage>

<passage><t376>No other animal on the farm could get past the letter A.</t376> <t377>It was also discovered that the most stupid ones, like the sheep, the hens, and the ducks, were incapable of memorizing the seven commandments.</t377> <t378>After much thought, Snowball declared that the seven commandments could be reduced to a single maxim expressed as: "Four legs good, two legs bad!"</t378> <t379>This, he said, contained the essential principle of Animalism.</t379> <t380>Anyone who fully understood it would be safeguarded against human influences.</t380> <t381>At first, the birds made certain objections because it seemed to them that they also had only two legs; but Snowball demonstrated to them that this was not the case.</t381></passage>

<passage><t382>—The wings of a bird —he explained— are propulsion organs and not for manipulation.</t382> <t383>Therefore, they should be considered as legs.</t383> <t384>The characteristic that distinguishes man is the "hand," a tool with which he commits all his excesses.</t384></passage>

<passage><t385>The birds did not fully understand Snowball's lengthy harangue, but they accepted his explanations, and even the most insignificant animals began to learn the new maxim by heart.</t385> <t386>"Four legs good, two legs bad!" was inscribed on the back wall of the barn, above the seven commandments and in larger letters.</t386> <t387>The sheep loved it, and once they had memorized it, they bleated it over and over again, even while resting on the field, and their "Four legs good, two legs bad!" could be heard for hours on end, repeated tirelessly.</t387></passage>

<passage><t388>Napoleon did not take an interest in the committees created by Snowball.</t388> <t389>He said that the education of the young was more important than anything that could be done for the adults.</t389> <t390>Meanwhile, it happened that Jessie and Bluebell had given birth shortly after the hay was harvested.</t390> <t391>Between the two of them, they had given the farm nine sturdy puppies.</t391> <t392>As soon as they were weaned, Napoleon separated them from their mothers, saying that he would take charge of their education.</t392> <t393>He took them to an attic, which could only be reached by a ladder from the harness room, and there he kept them in such a degree of seclusion that the rest of the farm soon forgot about their existence.</t393></passage>

<passage><t394>The mystery of the fate of the milk was soon clarified: it was mixed every day into the pigs' food.</t394> <t395>The first apples were already ripening, and the grass in the orchard was covered with fruit fallen from the trees.</t395> <t396>The animals naturally believed that this fruit would be distributed equitably; one day, however, the order was given that all fallen apples should be collected and taken to the harness-room for the pigs' consumption.</t396> <t397>Shortly after this happened, some animals began to murmur, but in vain.</t397> <t398>All the pigs agreed on this point, even Snowball and Napoleon.</t398> <t399>Squealer was sent to give the necessary explanations.</t399></passage>

<passage><t400>—Comrades —he shouted—, I imagine you don't suppose that we pigs are doing this with a spirit of selfishness and privilege.</t400> <t401>Many of us, in fact, have an aversion to milk and apples.</t401> <t402>Personally, I don't like them.</t402> <t403>Our only purpose in eating these foods is to preserve our health.</t403> <t404>Milk and apples (this has been proven by Science, comrades) contain substances absolutely necessary for the health of a pig.</t404> <t405>We pigs work with our brains.</t405> <t406>The entire administration and organization of this farm depend on us.</t406> <t407>Day and night we are watching over your happiness.</t407> <t408>For your sake, we take that milk and eat those apples.</t408> <t409>Do you know what would happen if we pigs failed in our duty?</t409> <t410>Jones would come back!</t410> <t411>Yes, Jones would come back!</t411> <t412>Surely, comrades —exclaimed Squealer almost pleadingly, dancing from side to side and wagging his tail—, surely there is no one among you who wants Jones to return.</t412></passage>

<passage><t413>Certainly, if there was one thing the animals were completely sure of, it was that they did not want Jones back.</t413> <t414>When it was presented to them in this way, they didn't know what to say.</t414> <t415>The importance of preserving the health of the pigs was too obvious.</t415> <t416>So it was decided without any discussion that the milk and the apples that had fallen from the trees (and also the main harvest of apples when they ripened) should be reserved exclusively for the pigs.</t416></passage>
<passage><t417>IV</t417></passage>

<passage><t418>BY the end of summer, the news of what had happened at "Animal Farm" had spread almost throughout the entire county.</t418> <t419>Every day, Snowball and Napoleon sent flocks of pigeons with instructions to mingle with the animals of the neighboring farms, tell them the story of the Rebellion, and teach them the tune of "Beasts of England."</t419></passage>

<passage><t420>For most of that time, Jones stayed at the "Red Lion" tavern in Willingdon, complaining to anyone who would listen about the monstrous injustice he had suffered by being thrown off his property by a band of useless animals.</t420> <t421>The other farmers sympathized with him, although they did not give him much help.</t421> <t422>Inwardly, each one secretly wondered if they could somehow turn Jones's misfortune to their own advantage.</t422> <t423>It was fortunate that the owners of the two farms adjoining "Animal Farm" were always at odds.</t423> <t424>One of them, called Foxwood, was a large, old-fashioned, and neglected farm, covered with woodland, with its grazing fields exhausted and its fences in a lamentable state.</t424> <t425>Its owner, Mr. Pilkington, was a gentlemanly and lazy farmer who spent most of his time fishing or hunting, depending on the season.</t425> <t426>The other farm, called Pinchfield, was smaller and better kept.</t426> <t427>Its owner, one Frederick, was a tough, shrewd man who was always involved in lawsuits and had a reputation as a skilled negotiator.</t427> <t428>The two hated each other so much that it was difficult for them to agree, even in defense of their own interests.</t428> <t429>Nevertheless, both were completely frightened by the rebellion at "Animal Farm" and very anxious to prevent their animals from learning too much about the event.</t429> <t430>At first, they pretended to laugh and scorn the idea of animals managing their own farm.</t430> <t431>"This whole thing will be over by tomorrow," they said to each other.</t431> <t432>They claimed that the animals at "Manor Farm" (they insisted on calling it "Manor Farm" because they could not tolerate the name "Animal Farm") were constantly fighting among themselves and would end up starving to death.</t432> <t433>After some time, and when the animals evidently did not starve, Frederick and Pilkington changed their tune and began to talk about the terrible wickedness flourishing at "Animal Farm."</t433> <t434>They spread the rumor that the animals practiced cannibalism, tortured each other with red-hot horseshoes, and practiced free love.</t434> <t435>"That is the result of rebelling against the laws of Nature," Frederick and Pilkington maintained.</t435></passage>

<passage><t436>However, these tales were never given much credit.</t436> <t437>Rumors about a wonderful farm from which humans had been expelled and where the animals managed their own affairs continued to circulate vaguely and falsely, and throughout that year a wave of rebellion spread across the region.</t437> <t438>Bulls that had always been docile suddenly turned wild; there were sheep that broke through fences and devoured the clover; cows that knocked over the buckets when being milked; hunting horses that refused to jump the hedges and threw their riders over their ears.</t438> <t439>Despite everything, the tune and even the lyrics of "Beasts of England" were known everywhere.</t439> <t440>They had spread with astonishing speed.</t440> <t441>Humans could not contain their fury when they heard this song, although they pretended to consider it simply ridiculous.</t441> <t442>They could not understand, they said, how even the animals themselves dared to sing something so despicable.</t442> <t443>Any animal caught singing it was whipped on the spot.</t443> <t444>However, the song proved irrepressible: blackbirds whistled it in the hedges, pigeons cooed it in the poplars, and it could even be recognized in the noise of the forges and the ringing of church bells.</t444> <t445>And when humans heard it, they secretly trembled, for they sensed in it a forewarning of their future doom.</t445></passage>

<passage><t446>In early October, when the corn had been cut and stacked and some of it had already been threshed, a flock of pigeons sped across and landed, very excited, in the yard of "Animal Farm."</t446> <t447>Jones and all his men, with half a dozen more men from Foxwood and Pinchfield, had crossed the gate and were approaching the house along the path.</t447> <t448>They were all wielding sticks, except for Jones, who marched ahead with a shotgun in his hand.</t448> <t449>Evidently, they were going to try to recapture the farm.</t449></passage>

<passage><t450>This eventuality had long been anticipated and, consequently, the necessary precautions had been taken.</t450> <t451>Snowball, who had studied Julius Caesar's campaigns in an old book found in the house, was in charge of the defensive operations.</t451> <t452>He gave the orders quickly and within a few minutes, each animal was in its combat position.</t452></passage>

<passage><t453>When the human beings approached the farm buildings, Snowball launched his first attack.</t453> <t454>All the pigeons—there were about thirty-five of them—flew over the men's heads and soiled them from above; and while the men were busy dodging what was falling on them, the geese, hidden behind the hedge, attacked them by furiously pecking at their calves.</t454> <t455>But that was a mere skirmish intended to create a bit of disorder, and the men easily drove the geese away with their sticks.</t455> <t456>Snowball launched the second line of attack: Muriel, Benjamin, and all the sheep, with Snowball at the head, advanced, charging and shoving the men from all sides, while Benjamin turned around and began kicking with his hind legs.</t456> <t457>But again, the men, with their sticks and hobnailed boots, were too strong for them, and suddenly, upon hearing Snowball's squeal, which was the signal to retreat, all the animals turned around and went through the gate into the yard.</t457></passage>

<passage><t458>The men let out a cry of triumph.</t458> <t459>They saw —or so they imagined— their enemies in flight and ran after them in disarray.</t459> <t460>That was precisely what Snowball had been expecting.</t460> <t461>As soon as they were inside the yard, the three horses, the three cows, and the other pigs, who had been lying in wait in the cowshed, suddenly appeared behind them, cutting off their retreat.</t461> <t462>Snowball gave the signal to charge.</t462> <t463>He himself attacked Jones.</t463> <t464>Jones saw him coming, aimed his shotgun, and fired.</t464> <t465>The pellets left their bloody mark on Snowball's back, and a sheep fell dead.</t465> <t466>Without hesitating for an instant, Snowball hurled his fifteen stone against Jones's legs, who fell onto a pile of manure as the shotgun slipped from his hands.</t466> <t467>But the most terrifying sight was Boxer, rearing up on his hind legs and kicking like a stallion with his enormous iron-shod hooves.</t467> <t468>His first blow struck a stable boy from Foxwood on the head, leaving him lying lifeless in the mud.</t468> <t469>Seeing this scene, several men dropped their sticks and tried to escape.</t469> <t470>But panic seized them, and in an instant, the animals were running after them all over the yard.</t470> <t471>They were gored, kicked, bitten, trampled.</t471> <t472>There was not a single animal on the farm that did not take revenge in its own way.</t472> <t473>Even the cat suddenly leaped from a rooftop onto a cowboy's back and sank its claws into his neck, making him scream horribly.</t473> <t474>When the exit was clear, the men were glad to escape the yard and flee like lightning to the main road.</t474> <t475>And so, five minutes after their invasion, they were in shameful retreat along the same access route, with a flock of geese pecking at their calves all the way.</t475></passage>

<passage><t476>All the men had left, except one.</t476> <t477>Out in the yard, Boxer was pushing with his hoof at the stable boy who lay face down in the mud, trying to turn him over.</t477> <t478>The boy did not move.</t478></passage>

<passage><t479>—He is dead —said Boxer sadly—.</t479> <t480>I didn't mean to do it.</t480> <t481>I forgot that I had horseshoes.</t481> <t482>Who is going to believe that I didn't do this on purpose?</t482></passage>
<passage><t483>—No sentimentality, comrade —shouted Snowball, from whose wounds blood was still flowing—.</t483> <t484>War is war.</t484> <t485>The only good human is a dead one.</t485></passage>
<passage><t486>—I do not wish to take a life, not even a human one —repeated Boxer with his eyes full of tears.</t486></passage>
<passage><t487>—Where is Mollie? —someone inquired.</t487></passage>

<passage><t488>Indeed, Mollie was missing.</t488> <t489>For a moment there was great alarm; it was feared that the men had harmed her in some way, or perhaps had taken her with them.</t489> <t490>In the end, they found her hiding in her stall, in the stable, with her head buried in the hay of the manger.</t490> <t491>She had run away as soon as the gunshot was fired.</t491> <t492>And, when the others returned from their search, they found that the stable boy, who was actually only stunned, had recovered and fled.</t492> <t493>The animals gathered very excitedly, each one loudly recounting their exploits in the battle.</t493> <t494>Immediately, an impromptu celebration of the victory took place.</t494> <t495>The flag was raised and "Beasts of England" was sung several times, and then a solemn burial was given to the sheep that died in the action, with a hawthorn branch planted over its grave.</t495> <t496>At this event, Snowball gave a speech, emphasizing the need for all animals to be willing to die for "Animal Farm," if necessary.</t496></passage>

<passage><t497>The animals unanimously decided to create a military decoration: "Animal Hero, First Class," which was immediately awarded to Snowball and Boxer.</t497> <t498>It consisted of a bronze medal (in reality, some bronze horse trappings found in the harness-room), which was to be worn on Sundays and holidays.</t498> <t499>They also created the "Animal Hero, Second Class," which was posthumously awarded to the dead sheep.</t499></passage>

<passage><t500>There was much discussion about the name that should be given to the battle.</t500> <t501>In the end, it was called the "Battle of the Cow Shed," as it was there where the ambush took place.</t501> <t502>Mr. Jones's shotgun was found in the mud, and it was known that there were shells in the house.</t502> <t503>It was decided to place the shotgun at the foot of the flagpole, as if it were a piece of artillery, and to fire it twice a year; once on October fourth, the anniversary of the "Battle of the Cow Shed," and the other on Midsummer Day, the anniversary of the Rebellion.</t503></passage>
<passage><t504>V</t504></passage>

<passage><t505>As winter approached, Mollie became more and more troublesome.</t505> <t506>She arrived late to work in the mornings with the excuse that she had overslept, complaining of mysterious ailments, even though her appetite was excellent.</t506> <t507>With any excuse, she would escape from work to go to the drinking pool, where she would stand staring at her reflection in the water like a fool.</t507> <t508>But there were also rumors of something more serious.</t508> <t509>One day, as Mollie was cheerfully entering the yard, swishing her long tail and chewing on a stalk of hay, Clover called her aside.</t509></passage>

<passage><t510>—Mollie —he said to her—, I have something very serious to tell you.</t510> <t511>This morning I saw you looking over the hedge that separates "Animal Farm" from Foxwood.</t511> <t512>One of Mr. Pilkington's men was on the other side of the hedge.</t512> <t513>And I was at a certain distance, but I am almost sure I saw you: he was talking to you and you were allowing him to pet you.</t513> <t514>What does that mean, Mollie?</t514></passage>
<passage><t515>—He did nothing!</t515> <t516>I wasn't there! It's not true! —shouted Mollie, prancing and kicking the ground.</t516></passage>
<passage><t517>—Mollie! Look me in the face.</t517> <t518>Can you give me your word of honor that that man was not petting your snout?</t518></passage>
<passage><t519>—It's not true! —repeated Mollie, but she couldn't look Clover in the face, and instantly she ran away, galloping towards the field.</t519></passage>

<passage><t520>A thought occurred to Clover.</t520> <t521>Without saying anything to anyone, she went to Mollie's stall and stirred the straw with her hoof.</t521> <t522>Hidden under the straw, there was a small pile of sugar lumps and several strips of ribbons of different colors.</t522> <t523>Three days later, Mollie disappeared.</t523> <t524>For several weeks, nothing was known about her whereabouts; then the pigeons reported that they had seen her on the other side of Willingdon.</t524> <t525>She was harnessed between the shafts of a smart red and black painted carriage, which was standing outside a tavern.</t525> <t526>A fat man, with a red face, wearing checkered breeches and gaiters, who looked like a publican, was stroking her nose and feeding her sugar.</t526> <t527>Mollie's coat was freshly clipped, and she wore a scarlet ribbon in her mane.</t527> <t528>“She appeared to be enjoying herself,” said the pigeons.</t528> <t529>None of the animals ever mentioned Mollie again.</t529> <t530>In January, the weather was very bad.</t530> <t531>The ground seemed like iron and nothing could be done in the fields.</t531> <t532>Many meetings were held in the big barn; the pigs were busy drawing up plans for the coming season.</t532> <t533>It was accepted that the pigs, who were manifestly more intelligent than the other animals, would decide all questions of farm management, though their decisions had to be ratified by a majority vote.</t533> <t534>This arrangement would have worked well enough if it had not been for the disputes between Snowball and Napoleon.</t534> <t535>The two disagreed at every point where disagreement was possible.</t535> <t536>If one of them suggested sowing a bigger acreage with barley, the other was certain to demand a larger acreage of oats; and if one said that such and such a field was just right for cabbages, the other would declare that it was good for turnips.</t536> <t537>Each had his own following, and there were violent debates at every meeting.</t537> <t538>In many ways, Snowball's brilliant speeches would win over the majority, but Napoleon was better at canvassing support for himself in between times.</t538> <t539>A peculiar incident was the behavior of the sheep, who had taken to bleating “Four legs good, two legs bad” at crucial moments in Snowball's speeches.</t539> <t540>It was noticed that they did this especially at critical moments in Snowball's speeches.</t540> <t541>He had made a close study of some back numbers of the “Farmer and Stockbreeder” which he had found in the farmhouse, and was full of plans for innovations and improvements.</t541> <t542>He talked learnedly about field drains, silage, and basic slag, and had worked out a complicated scheme for all the animals to drop their dung directly in the fields, at a different spot every day, to save the labor of cartage.</t542> <t543>Napoleon had no plans of his own to offer, but said quietly that Snowball's would come to nothing, and seemed to be biding his time.</t543> <t544>But of all their controversies, none was so bitter as the one that took place over the windmill.</t544></passage>

<passage><t545>In the long prairie, near the buildings, there was a small hill that was the highest point of the farm.</t545> <t546>After studying the terrain, Snowball declared that this was the ideal place for a windmill, which could be used to run a dynamo and supply electricity to the farm.</t546> <t547>This would provide light for the animals' stalls and heat them in winter, and it would also run a circular saw, a thresher, a cutter, an electric milker, etc.</t547> <t548>The animals had never heard of such things (because the farm was old-fashioned and had the most primitive machinery), and they listened in astonishment to Snowball as he described to them pictures of fantastic machinery that would work for them, while they grazed peacefully in the fields or improved their minds through reading and conversation.</t548></passage>

<passage><t549>In a few weeks, Snowball's plans for the windmill were completed.</t549> <t550>The technical details came mainly from three books that had belonged to Mr. Jones: "A Thousand Useful Things to Do Around the House," "Every Man His Own Bricklayer," and "Electricity for Beginners."</t550> <t551>As a study, Snowball used a shed that had once been used for incubators and had a smooth wooden floor, suitable for drawing.</t551> <t552>He would lock himself in there for hours on end.</t552> <t553>He kept his books open with a stone and, wielding a piece of chalk, moved quickly from side to side, drawing line after line and uttering small squeals of enthusiasm.</t553> <t554>Gradually, his plans transformed into a complicated mass of cranks and gears that covered more than half of the floor, which the other animals found completely indecipherable but very impressive.</t554> <t555>Everyone went to look at Snowball's plans at least once a day.</t555> <t556>Even the hens and ducks did so and took great care not to step on the chalk marks.</t556> <t557>Only Napoleon kept his distance.</t557> <t558>He had declared himself against the windmill from the beginning.</t558> <t559>One day, however, he unexpectedly came with the purpose of examining the plans.</t559> <t560>He walked heavily around, carefully observed every detail, and even sniffed once or twice; then he stood for a while, glancing at them sideways; then, suddenly, he lifted his leg, urinated on the plans, and walked away without saying a word.</t560></passage>

<passage><t561>The entire farm was very divided on the matter of the windmill.</t561> <t562>Snowball did not deny that the construction would mean difficult work.</t562> <t563>They would have to extract stones from the quarry and with them build walls, then construct the blades, and after all that, they would need dynamos and cables (how they would obtain those things, Snowball did not say).</t563> <t564>But he maintained that everything could be done in a year.</t564> <t565>And henceforth, he declared, so much work would be saved that the animals would only have three working days per week.</t565> <t566>Napoleon, on the other hand, maintained that the great need of the moment was to increase food production, and that if they wasted time on the windmill, they would all starve to death.</t566> <t567>The animals grouped into two factions under the slogans: "Vote for Snowball and the three-day week" and "Vote for Napoleon and the full manger."</t567> <t568>Benjamin was the only animal who did not enlist in either of the two sides.</t568> <t569>He refused to believe that there would be more abundance of food or that the windmill would save work.</t569> <t570>"With windmill or without windmill," he said, "life will go on as it always has, that is, a disaster."</t570></passage>

<passage><t571>Apart from the discussions regarding the windmill, there was the issue of the farm's defense.</t571> <t572>It was perfectly understood that although the humans had been defeated in the "Battle of the Cowshed," they might make another attempt, more determined than the previous one, to reclaim the farm and restore Mr. Jones.</t572> <t573>They had even greater reasons to do so, as the news of the defeat spread around and had made the animals more discontented than ever.</t573> <t574>As usual, Snowball and Napoleon were in disagreement.</t574> <t575>According to Napoleon, what the animals should do was procure firearms and train themselves in their use.</t575> <t576>Snowball believed they should send more and more pigeons and incite rebellion among the animals on the other farms.</t576> <t577>One argued that if they couldn't defend themselves, they were destined to be conquered; the other argued that if there were rebellions everywhere, they wouldn't need to defend themselves.</t577> <t578>The animals listened first to Napoleon, then to Snowball, and couldn't decide who was right; to be honest, they always agreed with whoever was speaking to them at the moment.</t578></passage>

<passage><t579>Finally, the day arrived when Snowball completed his plans.</t579> <t580>At the next Sunday Meeting, it would be put to a vote whether or not to start building the windmill.</t580> <t581>When the animals were gathered in the main barn, Snowball stood up and, although he was occasionally interrupted by the sheep's bleating, he laid out his reasons for defending the construction of the windmill.</t581> <t582>Then Napoleon stood up to respond.</t582> <t583>He calmly said that the windmill was nonsense and that he advised no one to vote for it.</t583> <t584>And he sat down immediately; he had spoken for barely thirty seconds, and he seemed indifferent to the effect he had produced.</t584> <t585>Next, Snowball jumped to his feet, and shouting to be heard despite the sheep, who had started bleating again, he launched into a passionate argument in favor of the windmill.</t585> <t586>Until then, the animals were more or less equally divided in their sympathies, but in an instant, Snowball's eloquence had convinced them.</t586> <t587>With fiery phrases, he painted a picture of what "Animal Farm" could be like when the vile labor was lifted from the animals' backs.</t587> <t588>His imagination had gone far beyond threshers and reapers.</t588> <t589>"Electricity," he said, "could power the threshers, plows, harrows, rollers, reapers, and binders, as well as provide each stall with its own electric light, cold and hot water, and an electric heater."</t589> <t590>When he finished speaking, there was no doubt about the outcome of the vote.</t590> <t591>But immediately Napoleon stood up and, casting a strange sidelong glance at Snowball, let out a high-pitched, shrill squeal that had never been heard from him before.</t591></passage>

<passage><t592>Immediately afterwards, terrible barking was heard coming from outside, and nine enormous dogs wearing collars studded with nails burst into the barn.</t592> <t593>And they went straight for Snowball, who jumped from his spot just in time to dodge their ferocious fangs.</t593> <t594>In an instant, he was on the other side of the door with the dogs after him.</t594> <t595>Too astonished and scared to say anything, all the animals crowded at the door to watch the chase.</t595> <t596>Snowball was running at full speed across the long meadow that led to the road.</t596> <t597>He ran as only a pig can, but the dogs were hot on his heels.</t597> <t598>Suddenly, he slipped and seemed to be easy prey for the dogs, but as soon as he regained his balance, he kept running faster than ever, though the hounds were gaining on him again.</t598> <t599>One of them was about to close its jaws on Snowball's tail, but he managed to dodge the bite just in time.</t599> <t600>And with a supreme effort, he managed to slip through a hole in the hedge, thus putting himself out of danger.</t600></passage>

<passage><t601>Silent and terrified, the animals stealthily returned to the barn.</t601> <t602>The dogs also returned, leaping about.</t602> <t603>At first, no one could imagine where those beasts had come from, but the problem was quickly clarified; they were the puppies that Napoleon had taken from their mothers and raised in seclusion.</t603> <t604>Although they were not yet fully grown, they were immense dogs, fierce as wolves.</t604> <t605>They never strayed far from Napoleon.</t605> <t606>And it was observed that they wagged their tails before him as the other dogs used to do with Mr. Jones.</t606></passage>

<passage><t607>Napoleon, with the dogs behind him, climbed onto the platform that Major had occupied when he delivered his historic speech.</t607> <t608>He announced that from that moment on, the Sunday morning meetings were over.</t608> <t609>They were unnecessary, he said, and wasted time.</t609> <t610>In the future, all matters related to the governance of the farm would be resolved by a special committee of pigs, presided over by him.</t610> <t611>They would meet in council and then communicate their decisions to the others.</t611> <t612>The animals would gather on Sunday mornings to salute the flag, sing "Beasts of England," and receive their orders for the week; but there would be no more debates.</t612> <t613>If the expulsion of Snowball had made a great impression on them, this announcement dismayed the animals.</t613> <t614>Some of them would have protested if they had the appropriate arguments.</t614> <t615>Even Boxer was a bit stunned.</t615> <t616>He pricked his ears back, shook his mane several times, and tried hard to organize his thoughts; but in the end, he couldn't think of anything to say.</t616> <t617>Some pigs, however, were more expressive.</t617> <t618>Four young pigs in the front row emitted sharp cries of disapproval, and they all stood up abruptly and began to speak at the same time.</t618> <t619>But suddenly, the dogs sitting around Napoleon let out deep, threatening growls, and the pigs fell silent, sitting back down.</t619> <t620>Then the sheep burst out with a tremendous bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad!" which continued for almost a quarter of an hour and ended all attempts at discussion.</t620></passage>
<passage><t621>Then Squealer was sent all over the farm to explain the new decisions to the others.</t621></passage>

<passage><t622>—Comrades —he said—, I hope that all the animals present will realize and appreciate the sacrifice that Comrade Napoleon has made by taking on this additional work.</t622> <t623>Do not think, comrades, that being a leader is a pleasure!</t623> <t624>On the contrary, it is a deep and heavy responsibility.</t624> <t625>No one believes more firmly than Comrade Napoleon in the principle that all animals are equal.</t625> <t626>He would be very happy to let you make your own decisions.</t626> <t627>But sometimes you might make the wrong decisions, comrades.</t627> <t628>And where would we be then?</t628> <t629>Suppose you had decided to follow Snowball, with his ridiculous windmills; Snowball, who, as we now know, was nothing more than a criminal…</t629></passage>
<passage><t630>—He fought valiantly in the "Battle of the Cow Shed" —someone said.</t630></passage>

<passage><t631>—Bravery is not enough —affirmed Squealer—.</t631> <t632>Loyalty and obedience are more important.</t632> <t633>And as for the "Battle of the Cowshed," I believe that the day will come when we will prove that the role played by Snowball has been greatly exaggerated.</t633> <t634>Discipline, comrades, iron discipline!</t634> <t635>That is the watchword for today.</t635> <t636>One misstep, and our enemies would fall upon us.</t636> <t637>Surely, comrades, you do not want the return of Jones, do you?</t637></passage>

<passage><t638>Once again, this argument proved irrefutable.</t638> <t639>It was clear that the animals did not want Jones to return; if holding debates on Sunday mornings could imply his return, then the debates had to be abolished.</t639> <t640>Boxer, who had had time to coordinate his thoughts, expressed the general opinion by saying: "If Comrade Napoleon says it, it must be right."</t640> <t641>And from that moment on, he adopted the slogan: "Napoleon is always right," in addition to his personal motto: "I will work harder."</t641> <t642>By then the weather had changed and the spring plowing had begun.</t642> <t643>The shed where Snowball had drawn the plans for the windmill was closed, and it was assumed that the plans had been erased from the floor.</t643> <t644>Every Sunday at ten in the morning, the animals gathered in the main barn to receive their orders for the week.</t644> <t645>The skull of Old Major, now devoid of flesh, had been unearthed from the orchard and placed on a post at the foot of the flagpole, next to the shotgun.</t645> <t646>After raising the flag, the animals had to parade reverently past the skull before entering the barn.</t646> <t647>They no longer sat all together as they used to.</t647> <t648>Napoleon, with Squealer and another pig named Minimus, who had an extraordinary gift for composing songs and poems, sat on the platform, with the nine dogs forming a semicircle around them, and the other pigs positioned behind them.</t648> <t649>The other animals placed themselves in front, in the main body of the barn.</t649> <t650>Napoleon read them the orders for the week in a harsh military style, and after singing "Beasts of England" once, all the animals dispersed.</t650></passage>

<passage><t651>On the third Sunday after Snowball's expulsion, the animals were somewhat surprised to hear Napoleon announce that, after all, the windmill would be built.</t651> <t652>He gave no explanation for this change of mind, but simply warned the animals that this extraordinary task would mean very hard work; it might be necessary to reduce their rations.</t652> <t653>The plans, however, had been prepared down to the smallest detail.</t653> <t654>A special committee of pigs had been working on them for the past three weeks.</t654> <t655>The construction of the windmill, along with other planned improvements, would require two years of work.</t655></passage>

<passage><t656>That very night, Squealer privately explained to the other animals that in reality, Napoleon had never been against the windmill.</t656> <t657>On the contrary, it was he who advocated for its construction, and the plan that Snowball had drawn on the floor of the incubator shed was actually stolen from Napoleon's papers.</t657> <t658>The windmill was truly a creation of Napoleon himself.</t658> <t659>“Why, then,” someone asked, “did he so firmly oppose the windmill?” Here Squealer put on a cunning face.</t659> <t660>“That,” he said, “was the sagacity of Comrade Napoleon.”</t660> <t661>He had pretended to oppose the windmill, but simply as a maneuver to get rid of Snowball, who was a dangerous and harmful influence.</t661> <t662>Now that Snowball had been eliminated, the plan could proceed without his interference.</t662> <t663>“This,” said Squealer, “is what is called tactics.”</t663> <t664>He repeated several times, “Tactics, comrades, tactics!” jumping and wagging his tail with a cheerful laugh.</t664> <t665>The animals were not certain about the meaning of the word, but Squealer spoke so persuasively, and three of the dogs that were with him growled so threateningly, that they accepted his explanation without further questions.</t665></passage>
<passage><t666>VI</t666></passage>

<passage><t667>All that year, the animals worked like slaves.</t667> <t668>But they were happy in their task; they did not spare any effort or sacrifice, for they knew well that everything they did was for their own benefit and for those of their kind who would come after, and not for a few greedy and lazy human beings.</t668></passage>

<passage><t669>Throughout the entire spring and summer, they worked sixty hours a week, and in August, Napoleon announced that they would also have to work on Sunday afternoons.</t669> <t670>This work was strictly voluntary, but any animal that did not show up would have their rations cut in half.</t670> <t671>Even so, it was necessary to leave several tasks undone.</t671> <t672>The harvest was somewhat less abundant than the previous year, and two plots that should have been planted with turnips at the beginning of the summer were not because they were not plowed in time.</t672> <t673>It was easy to foresee that the next winter would be harsh.</t673></passage>
