<passage><t674>The windmill presented unexpected difficulties.</t674> <t675>There was a good limestone quarry on the farm, and quite a bit of sand and cement was found in one of the outbuildings, so they had all the necessary materials for construction on hand.</t675> <t676>But the problem, which the animals could not solve at first, was how to break the stone into appropriately sized pieces.</t676> <t677>Apparently, there was no way to do it except with picks and iron levers, which they could not use because no animal was able to stand on its hind legs.</t677> <t678>After several weeks of futile efforts, one of them came up with the right idea, namely: to use the force of gravity.</t678> <t679>Immense stones, too large to use as they were, were found all over the bottom of the quarry.</t679> <t680>The animals tied them with ropes, and then all together, cows, horses, sheep, anyone who could pull the rope —even the pigs sometimes helped in critical moments— dragged them with exasperating slowness up the slope to the top of the quarry, from where they let them fall over the edge to break into pieces upon hitting the bottom.</t680> <t681>The work of transporting the stone once broken was relatively simple.</t681> <t682>The horses carried the pieces in carts, the sheep dragged them one by one, and even Muriel and Benjamin, pulling an old sulky, did their part.</t682> <t683>By the end of summer, they had accumulated a good supply of stone, and it was then that the construction of the windmill began, under the supervision of the pigs.</t683></passage>

<passage><t684>It was a slow and laborious process.</t684> <t685>Frequently, it took them an entire day of exhausting effort to drag a single stone to the top of the quarry, and sometimes, when they threw it off the cliff, it wouldn't break.</t685> <t686>They wouldn't have been able to achieve anything without Boxer, whose strength seemed to equal that of all the other animals combined.</t686> <t687>When the stone started to slip and the animals cried out in desperation as they were dragged down the slope, it was always Boxer who, pulling on the rope like a convict, managed to stop the stone.</t687> <t688>Seeing him dragging it up the incline, inch by inch, panting, digging the tips of his hooves into the ground, and his enormous flanks sweaty, filled everyone with admiration.</t688> <t689>Clover sometimes warned him to be careful and not to overexert himself, but Boxer never paid attention.</t689> <t690>His two mottos: "I will work harder" and "Napoleon is always right," seemed to him a satisfactory answer to all problems.</t690> <t691>He had arranged with the rooster to wake him up three-quarters of an hour earlier in the morning, instead of half an hour.</t691> <t692>And in his free time, of which he had very little these days, he would go to the quarry, gather a pile of stone pieces, and drag it by himself to the site of the windmill.</t692></passage>

<passage><t693>The animals did not have such a hard time throughout that summer, despite the harshness of their work.</t693> <t694>If they did not have more food than they had during Jones's time, they did not have less either.</t694> <t695>The advantage of feeding themselves and not having to also support five useless human beings was so great that it would have taken countless failures to lose it.</t695> <t696>And in many situations, the animal method of doing things was more efficient than the human one and saved labor.</t696> <t697>Some tasks, such as weeding, could be done with an efficiency impossible for human beings.</t697> <t698>And besides, since no animal stole, it was not necessary to build fences to separate the pastures from the arable land, which saved a lot of work in maintaining the hedges and fences.</t698> <t699>However, as the summer progressed, an unforeseen shortage of various things began to be felt.</t699> <t700>There was a need for paraffin oil, nails, biscuits for the dogs, and iron for the horseshoes, none of which could be produced on the farm.</t700></passage>

<passage><t701>Later on, there would also be a need for seeds and artificial fertilizers, as well as various tools and, finally, the most important thing: the machinery for the windmill.</t701> <t702>Nobody could imagine how all these items were going to be obtained.</t702></passage>

<passage><t703>One Sunday morning, when the animals gathered to receive orders, Napoleon announced that he had decided to adopt a new system.</t703> <t704>Henceforth, "Animal Farm" would negotiate with the neighboring farms; and not, of course, for any commercial purpose, but simply to obtain certain materials that were urgently needed.</t704> <t705>"The needs of the windmill are above everything else," he stated.</t705> <t706>Consequently, he was taking the necessary measures to sell a portion of the hay and another part of that year's wheat harvest, and later on, if they needed more money, they would have to obtain it by selling eggs, for which there was always a market in Willingdon.</t706> <t707>"The hens," said Napoleon, "should gladly accept this sacrifice as a special contribution to the construction of the windmill."</t707></passage>

<passage><t708>Once again the animals felt themselves gripped by a vague unease.</t708> <t709>“Never to have any dealings with humans, never to engage in trade, never to use money,” weren’t those the first resolutions adopted at that triumphant meeting, after Jones had been expelled?</t709> <t710>All the animals remembered having approved such resolutions or, at least, they believed they remembered it.</t710> <t711>The four young pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the meetings timidly raised their voices, but were immediately silenced by the fierce growling of the dogs.</t711> <t712>Then, as usual, the sheep burst out with their “Four legs good, two legs bad!” and their chant prevailed.</t712> <t713>Finally, Napoleon raised his paw to impose silence and announced that he had already decided all the agreements.</t713> <t714>There would be no need for any of the animals to come into contact with human beings, which would be undesirable.</t714> <t715>He intended to take the full weight of the decisions upon his own shoulders.</t715> <t716>A certain Mr. Whymper, a broker who lived in Willingdon, had agreed to act as an intermediary between “Animal Farm” and the outside world, and would visit the farm every Monday morning to receive instructions.</t716> <t717>Napoleon ended his speech with his usual cry of “Long live Animal Farm!” and after singing “Beasts of England,” he dismissed the animals.</t717></passage>

<passage><t718>Then Squealer went around the farm and reassured them.</t718> <t719>He assured them that the resolution prohibiting trade and the use of money had never been passed, nor even suggested.</t719> <t720>It was pure imagination, probably attributable to lies spread by Snowball.</t720> <t721>Some animals still had certain doubts, but Squealer cunningly asked them: "Are you sure this isn't something you have dreamed, comrades?</t721> <t722>Do you have any record of such a resolution?</t722> <t723>Is it written down anywhere?"</t723> <t724>And since it was true that none of this was written down, the animals were convinced that they were mistaken.</t724></passage>

<passage><t725>Every Monday, Mr. Whymper visited the farm, as had been agreed.</t725> <t726>He was a short, cunning man with broad sideburns, a retail broker, but smart enough to realize, before anyone else, that "Animal Farm" was going to need an agent and that the commissions would be worth it.</t726> <t727>The animals watched his comings and goings with some fear, and avoided him as much as possible.</t727> <t728>However, the sight of Napoleon, on his four legs, giving orders to Whymper, who stood on his two feet, stirred their pride and partially reconciled them to the new situation.</t728> <t729>Their relations with the human race were not as they had been before.</t729> <t730>The humans, for their part, did not hate "Animal Farm" any less now that it was prospering; on the contrary, they hated it more than ever.</t730> <t731>Every human was certain that, sooner or later, the farm would go bankrupt, and above all, that the windmill would be a failure.</t731> <t732>They gathered in taverns and demonstrated to each other, through diagrams, that the windmill was destined to fall or, if it stood, that it would never work.</t732> <t733>And yet, against their wishes, they came to have a certain respect for the efficiency with which the animals were managing their own affairs.</t733> <t734>One of the signs of this was that they began to call "Animal Farm" by its real name and stopped pretending it was called "Manor Farm."</t734> <t735>They also ceased to support Jones, who had lost hope of regaining his farm and went to live elsewhere in the country.</t735> <t736>Except for Whymper, there was still no contact between "Animal Farm" and the outside world, but there were constant rumors that Napoleon was definitely going to make a trade agreement with Mr. Pilkington of Foxwood, or with Mr. Frederick of Pinchfield; but never — it was noted — with both simultaneously.</t736></passage>

<passage><t737>It was around that time when the pigs suddenly moved into the farmhouse and established their residence there.</t737> <t738>Once again, the animals thought they remembered that in the early days a resolution had been passed against such a measure, and once again Squealer had to convince them that it was not so.</t738> <t739>It was absolutely necessary, he said, that the pigs, who were the brains of the farm, had a quiet place to work.</t739></passage>

<passage><t740>It was also more appropriate for the dignity of the Leader (because lately they had begun to refer to Napoleon with the title of "Leader") that he lived in a house instead of a simple pigsty.</t740> <t741>However, some animals were upset to learn that the pigs not only ate in the kitchen and used the living room as a recreation area, but also slept in the beds.</t741> <t742>Boxer overlooked it, as usual, repeating "Napoleon is always right!", but Clover, who believed she remembered a specific provision against beds, went to the end of the barn and tried to decipher the seven commandments that were written there.</t742> <t743>Seeing that she could only read the letters one by one, she brought Muriel.</t743></passage>
<passage><t744>—Muriel —he said—, read me the fourth commandment.</t744> <t745>Doesn't it say something about never sleeping in a bed?</t745></passage>
<passage><t746>With a bit of difficulty, Muriel spelled it out.</t746></passage>
<passage><t747>—He says: "No animal shall sleep in a bed with sheets."</t747></passage>

<passage><t748>The curious thing was that Clover did not remember the Fourth Commandment mentioning the sheets; but since it was written on the wall, it must have been so.</t748> <t749>And Squealer, who was passing by at that moment, accompanied by two or three dogs, was able to clarify the matter and set it straight.</t749></passage>

<passage>
    <t750>—You have heard, comrades —he said—, that we pigs now sleep in the beds of the house.</t750>
    <t751>And why not?</t751>
    <t752>Surely, you would not suppose that there was ever a ruling against beds.</t752>
    <t753>A bed simply means a place to sleep.</t753>
    <t754>For example: a pile of straw in a barn is a bed.</t754>
    <t755>The resolution was against the sheets, which are an invention of human beings.</t755>
    <t756>We have removed the sheets from the beds in the house and sleep between blankets.</t756>
    <t757>And indeed, they are very comfortable beds!</t757>
    <t758>But they are no more than what we need, I can assure you, comrades, considering all the brainwork we have these days.</t758>
    <t759>You wouldn't want to deprive us of our rest, would you, comrades?</t759>
    <t760>You wouldn't want us to be so tired that we can't fulfill our duties.</t760>
    <t761>Surely, none of you would want Jones to come back.</t761>
</passage>

<passage><t762>The animals immediately calmed him down and the matter of the pigs sleeping in the house beds was not discussed further.</t762> <t763>And when, days later, it was announced that from then on the pigs would get up an hour later in the morning than the other animals, there was no complaint about it either.</t763></passage>

<passage><t764>When autumn arrived, the animals were tired but happy.</t764> <t765>They had had a difficult year and after selling some of the hay and corn, the food supplies were not as abundant, but the windmill made up for everything.</t765> <t766>It was almost built.</t766> <t767>After the harvest, they had a season of dry and clear weather, and the animals worked harder than ever, thinking it was well worth running back and forth all day with stone blocks if by doing so they could raise the walls another foot in height.</t767> <t768>Boxer even sometimes went out at night and worked an hour or two on his own by moonlight.</t768> <t769>In their free time, the animals walked around and around the almost finished windmill, admiring the strength and verticality of its walls and marveling that they had ever been able to build something so imposing.</t769> <t770>Only old Benjamin refused to get excited about the windmill, although, as usual, he insisted on his enigmatic statement that donkeys lived a long time.</t770></passage>

<passage><t771>November arrived, with its furious southwest winds.</t771> <t772>They had to stop the construction because there was too much humidity to mix the cement.</t772> <t773>And then came a night when the gale was so violent that the farm buildings trembled on their foundations and several tiles were torn off the barn roof.</t773> <t774>The hens woke up clucking in terror because they all dreamed they had heard something like the boom of a cannon in the distance.</t774> <t775>In the morning, the animals came out of their stalls and found the flagpole knocked down and an elm tree, which was at the foot of the orchard, uprooted.</t775> <t776>They had barely seen this when a cry of despair burst from their throats.</t776> <t777>A terrible scene presented itself to their eyes.</t777> <t778>The windmill was in ruins.</t778></passage>

<passage><t779>All at once they rushed towards the place.</t779> <t780>Napoleon, who rarely hurried when walking, was running at the head of all of them.</t780> <t781>Yes, there lay the fruit of all their efforts, demolished to its foundations; the stones, which they had so diligently broken and moved, were scattered everywhere.</t781> <t782>Unable, at first, to utter a word, they could only look sadly at the fallen rubble in disarray.</t782> <t783>Napoleon walked back and forth in silence, occasionally sniffing the ground.</t783> <t784>His tail had gone stiff and was moving nervously from side to side, a sign of his intense mental activity.</t784> <t785>Suddenly he stopped as if he had clearly seen the origin of that disaster.</t785></passage>

<passage><t786>—Comrades —he said in a calm voice—, do you know who is responsible for all this?</t786> <t787>Do you know who the enemy is that came during the night and knocked down our windmill? Snowball! —he suddenly roared with a thunderous voice—.</t787> <t788>Snowball did this!</t788> <t789>Out of pure malice, believing that he was going to ruin our plans and take revenge for his ignominious expulsion, that traitor crawled here under the cover of darkness and destroyed our work of nearly a year.</t789> <t790>Comrades, at this moment and place, I sentence Snowball to death.</t790> <t791>I will reward and name "Animal Hero, Second Class" and give half a bushel of apples to the animal that brings him dead.</t791> <t792>A whole bushel to the one who captures him alive.</t792></passage>

<passage><t793>The animals were horrified to learn that Snowball could be guilty of such an action.</t793> <t794>There was a cry of indignation and everyone began to devise a way to catch Snowball, if they ever found him.</t794> <t795>Almost immediately, the footprints of a pig were discovered in the grass, a short distance from the hill.</t795> <t796>The tracks could be followed for a few meters, but they seemed to lead to a hole in the hedge.</t796> <t797>Napoleon sniffed them well and declared that they were Snowball's.</t797> <t798>He opined that Snowball had probably come from "Foxwood Farm."</t798></passage>

<passage><t799>—There is no time to lose, comrades! —shouted Napoleon once he had examined the footprints—.</t799> <t800>There is much work to be done.</t800> <t801>This very morning we will start rebuilding the windmill and we will reconstruct it throughout the winter, come rain or shine.</t801> <t802>We will show that miserable traitor that he cannot undo our work so easily.</t802> <t803>Remember, comrades; there must be no alteration in our plans, which will be carried out no matter what.</t803> <t804>Forward, comrades! Long live the windmill! Long live "Animal Farm"!</t804></passage>
<passage><t805>VII</t805></passage>

<passage><t806>A harsh winter set in.</t806> <t807>The stormy weather was followed by hail and snow and then by a severe frost that lasted until mid-February.</t807> <t808>The animals managed as best they could to rebuild the windmill, for they knew well that the outside world was watching them and that the envious humans would rejoice and triumph over them if they did not finish the work on time.</t808></passage>

<passage><t809>Resentful, the humans pretended not to believe that it was Snowball who had destroyed the windmill; they claimed it collapsed because the walls were too thin.</t809> <t810>The animals knew that wasn't true.</t810> <t811>Despite this, they decided to build the walls one meter thick instead of half a meter as before, which meant gathering a much larger amount of stones.</t811> <t812>For a long time, the quarry was completely covered by a layer of snow and nothing could be done.</t812> <t813>Some progress was made during the dry and cold period that followed, but it was a cruel labor and the animals did not feel as optimistic as before.</t813> <t814>They were always cold and often hungry.</t814> <t815>Only Boxer and Clover never lost heart.</t815> <t816>Squealer gave magnificent speeches about the pride of service and the dignity of labor, but the other animals found more inspiration in Boxer's strength and his unfailing cry: "I will work harder!"</t816></passage>

<passage><t817>In January, food was scarce.</t817> <t818>The corn ration was drastically reduced, and it was announced that, in compensation, a supplementary ration of potatoes would be given.</t818> <t819>But then it was discovered that most of the potato harvest had frozen due to insufficient protection.</t819> <t820>The tubers had softened and discolored, and very few were edible.</t820> <t821>For entire days, the animals had nothing to eat except straw and beets.</t821> <t822>The specter of hunger seemed to stare them in the face.</t822></passage>

<passage><t823>It was absolutely necessary to hide that from the outside world.</t823> <t824>Encouraged by the collapse of the windmill, humans were inventing new lies about "Animal Farm."</t824> <t825>Once again, it was being spread that all the animals were dying of hunger and disease, that they were constantly fighting among themselves, and had fallen into cannibalism and infanticide.</t825> <t826>Napoleon was well aware of the disastrous consequences that would result from the discovery of the true food situation, and decided to use Mr. Whymper to spread a contrary impression.</t826> <t827>Until then, the animals had little or no contact with Whymper during his weekly visits; now, however, a few selected beasts, mostly sheep, were instructed to casually comment within his hearing range that the rations had been increased.</t827> <t828>Moreover, Napoleon ordered that the nearly empty bins in the sheds be filled to the top with sand and then covered with what little grain and forage remained.</t828> <t829>Under an appropriate pretext, Whymper was led through those sheds and allowed to take a look at the bins.</t829> <t830>They managed to deceive him, and he continued to report to the outside world that there was no food shortage on "Animal Farm."</t830></passage>

<passage><t831>However, by the end of January, it was evident that there was a need to obtain more grain from somewhere.</t831> <t832>During those days, Napoleon rarely appeared in public; he spent all his time inside the house, whose doors were guarded by fierce-looking dogs.</t832> <t833>When he did appear, it was in a ceremonious manner, with an escort of six dogs that closely surrounded him and growled if anyone came too close.</t833> <t834>He was no longer seen on Sunday mornings either, but gave his orders through another pig, who was usually Squealer.</t834> <t835>One Sunday morning, Squealer announced that the hens, who were starting to lay eggs again, had to deliver their eggs.</t835> <t836>Napoleon had signed, through Whymper, a contract to sell four hundred eggs weekly.</t836> <t837>The price of these would be enough to buy a sufficient amount of grain and food, and would allow the farm to subsist until summer arrived and conditions improved.</t837></passage>

<passage><t838>When the hens heard this, they raised a great clamor.</t838> <t839>They had been warned beforehand that this sacrifice would be necessary, but they did not believe that this reality would come to pass.</t839> <t840>They were preparing their nests to brood in the spring and protested, saying that taking their eggs was a crime.</t840> <t841>For the first time since Jones's expulsion, there was something resembling a rebellion.</t841> <t842>Led by three young Black Minorca hens, the hens made a determined attempt to thwart Napoleon's wishes.</t842> <t843>Their protest was to fly up to the rafters and lay their eggs there, which shattered upon hitting the ground.</t843> <t844>Napoleon acted quickly and mercilessly.</t844> <t845>He ordered that the hens' rations be suspended and decreed that any animal giving even a grain of corn to a hen would be punished with death.</t845> <t846>The dogs ensured that the orders were carried out.</t846> <t847>The hens held out for five days, then capitulated and returned to their nests.</t847> <t848>Nine hens died in the meantime.</t848> <t849>Their bodies were buried in the orchard and it was reported that they had died of coccidiosis.</t849> <t850>Whymper did not find out about this matter and the eggs were duly delivered; the grocer's van came to the farm weekly to collect them.</t850></passage>

<passage><t851>During all this time there were no signs of Snowball.</t851> <t852>It was rumored that he was hiding in one of the neighboring farms: Foxwood or Pinchfield.</t852> <t853>Napoleon maintained better relations than before with the other farmers.</t853> <t854>And it happened that in the yard there was a pile of timber for construction, which had been there for ten years, since a beech forest was felled.</t854> <t855>It was well maintained and Whymper advised Napoleon to sell it; both Mr. Pilkington and Mr. Frederick were eager to buy it.</t855> <t856>Napoleon was undecided between the two, unable to make a resolution.</t856> <t857>It was noted that when he seemed about to reach an agreement with Frederick, it was said that Snowball was hiding in Foxwood, and when he leaned towards Pilkington, it was claimed that Snowball was in Pinchfield.</t857></passage>

<passage><t858>Suddenly, at the beginning of spring, something alarming was discovered.</t858> <t859>Snowball was secretly frequenting the farm at night!</t859> <t860>The animals were so disturbed that they could barely sleep in their stables.</t860></passage>

<passage><t861>Every night, it was said, he would sneak in under the cover of darkness and cause all sorts of damage.</t861> <t862>He would steal the corn, overturn the milk pails, break the eggs, trample the seedlings, gnaw the bark of the fruit trees.</t862> <t863>Whenever something went wrong, it became customary to always attribute it to Snowball.</t863> <t864>If a window was broken or a drain was clogged, it was a sure thing that someone would say Snowball had done it during the night, and when the key to the food shed was lost, the entire farm was convinced that Snowball had thrown it down the well.</t864> <t865>Curiously enough, they continued to believe this even after the lost key was found under a sack of flour.</t865> <t866>The cows unanimously declared that Snowball had slipped into their stalls and milked them while they slept.</t866> <t867>It was also said that the mice, which had been quite troublesome that winter, were in league with Snowball.</t867></passage>

<passage><t868>Napoleon ordered a thorough investigation of Snowball's activities.</t868> <t869>With his entourage of dogs, he went out to inspect the farm buildings, followed at a prudent distance by the other animals.</t869> <t870>Every few steps, Napoleon would stop and sniff the ground, searching for traces of Snowball's footprints, which he claimed he could recognize by scent.</t870> <t871>He sniffed in every corner, in the barn, in the cow shed, in the henhouses, in the vegetable garden, and found traces of Snowball almost everywhere.</t871> <t872>Pressing his snout to the ground, he would sniff deeply several times and then exclaim in a terrible voice: "Snowball!</t872> <t873>He has been here! I can smell him perfectly!" and upon hearing the word "Snowball," all the dogs would let out horrible growls and bare their fangs.</t873></passage>

<passage><t874>The animals were completely terrified.</t874> <t875>It seemed to them that Snowball was a kind of invisible curse that infested the breathable air and threatened them with all kinds of dangers.</t875> <t876>At dusk, Squealer gathered them all, and with a troubled face, announced that he had serious news to communicate to them.</t876></passage>

<passage><t877>—Comrades —shouted Squealer, making some nervous little jumps—, something terrible has been discovered!</t877> <t878>Snowball has sold himself to Frederick, from "Pinchfield Farm," and at this very moment he must be conspiring to attack us and take our farm!</t878> <t879>Snowball will act as a guide when the attack begins.</t879> <t880>But there is something even worse.</t880> <t881>We had believed that Snowball's rebellion was motivated simply by his vanity and ambition.</t881> <t882>But we were wrong, comrades.</t882> <t883>Do you know what the real reason was?</t883> <t884>Snowball was in agreement with Jones from the very beginning!</t884> <t885>He has always been Jones's secret agent.</t885> <t886>This has been proven by documents he left behind and that we have now discovered.</t886> <t887>To me, this explains many things, comrades: haven't we seen ourselves how he tried, fortunately without success, to provoke our defeat and annihilation in the "Battle of the Cowshed"?</t887></passage>

<passage><t888>The animals were stunned.</t888> <t889>That was an evil much greater than the destruction of the windmill.</t889> <t890>But it took them several minutes to understand its meaning.</t890> <t891>They all remembered, or thought they remembered, how they had seen Snowball leading the attack in the "Battle of the Cowshed," how he had rallied and encouraged them at every setback, and how he had not hesitated for a single moment, even though Jones's shotgun pellets had wounded him in the back.</t891> <t892>At first, it was a bit difficult to understand how all this fit with the fact that he was on Jones's side.</t892> <t893>Even Boxer, who rarely asked questions, was perplexed.</t893> <t894>He lay down, tucked his front legs under his chest, closed his eyes, and with great effort managed to piece together his thoughts.</t894></passage>

<passage><t895>—I don't believe that —he said—, Snowball fought bravely in the "Battle of the Cowshed."</t895> <t896>I saw it myself.</t896> <t897>Didn't we immediately award him the "Animal Hero, First Class" right after?</t897></passage>

<passage><t898>—That was our mistake, comrade.</t898> <t899>Because now we know —it is all written in the secret documents we have found— that in reality, he was dragging us towards our ruin.</t899></passage>
<passage><t900>—But he was wounded —argued Boxer—.</t900> <t901>We all saw him bleeding.</t901></passage>
<passage><t902>—That was part of the agreement! —shouted Squealer—.</t902> <t903>Jones's shot only grazed him.</t903></passage>

<passage><t904>I could prove this to you, which is written in his own handwriting, if you could read it.</t904> <t905>The plan was that Snowball, at the critical moment, would give the signal to retreat, leaving the field in the enemy's hands.</t905> <t906>And he almost succeeded: I will say more, comrades: he would have succeeded if it weren't for our heroic Leader, comrade Napoleon.</t906> <t907>Do you remember how, at the precise moment when Jones and his men reached the yard, Snowball suddenly turned and fled, and many animals followed him?</t907> <t908>And do you also remember that just at that moment, when panic spread and it seemed that all was lost, comrade Napoleon leaped forward with the cry of "Death to Humanity!" and sank his teeth into Jones's leg?</t908> <t909>Surely you have not forgotten this, comrades — exclaimed Squealer.</t909></passage>
<passage><t910>As Squealer described the scene so graphically, it seemed to the animals that they remembered it.</t910></passage>
<passage><t911>In any case, they knew that at the critical moment of the battle, Snowball had turned to flee.</t911> <t912>But Boxer was still somewhat undecided.</t912></passage>

<passage><t913>—I don't believe that Snowball was a traitor at the beginning —he finally said—.</t913> <t914>What he may have done since then is different.</t914> <t915>But I believe that in the "Battle of the Cowshed" he was a good comrade.</t915></passage>

<passage><t916>—Our Leader, Comrade Napoleon —announced Squealer, speaking slowly and firmly—, has categorically, categorically, comrades, stated that Snowball was Jones's agent from the very beginning of everything and in any case, long before the Rebellion was even thought of.</t916></passage>
<passage><t917>—Ah, that's different! —shouted Boxer—.</t917> <t918>If Comrade Napoleon says so, it must be true.</t918></passage>

<passage><t919>—That's the true spirit, comrade! —shouted Squealer, but it was noticeable that he cast a sullen glance at Boxer with his flashing little eyes.</t919> <t920>He turned to leave, then stopped and added impressively—:</t920> <t921>I warn every animal on this farm to keep their eyes wide open, because we have reason to believe that some of Snowball's secret agents are among us and lurking at this very moment!</t921></passage>

<passage><t922>Four days later, at dusk, Napoleon ordered the animals to gather in the yard.</t922> <t923>When they were all assembled, Napoleon emerged from the house, wearing his two medals (because he had recently named himself "Animal Hero First Class" and "Animal Hero Second Class"), with his nine enormous dogs leaping around and emitting growls that sent chills down the other animals' spines.</t923> <t924>They all quietly took their places, seeming to know in advance that terrible things were about to happen.</t924></passage>

<passage><t925>Napoleon stood observing his audience sternly; then he let out a sharp growl.</t925> <t926>Immediately, the dogs leaped forward, grabbed four of the pigs by their ears, and dragged them, terrified and squealing in pain, to Napoleon's feet.</t926> <t927>The pigs' ears were bleeding; the dogs had tasted blood and for a few moments seemed crazed.</t927> <t928>To everyone's astonishment, three of them pounced on Boxer.</t928> <t929>He saw them coming and stretched out his enormous hoof, caught one in mid-air, and pinned it to the ground.</t929> <t930>The dog squealed for mercy and the others fled with their tails between their legs.</t930> <t931>Boxer looked at Napoleon to see if he should continue crushing the dog to death or if he should release it.</t931> <t932>Napoleon seemed to change his expression and brusquely ordered him to release the dog, to which Boxer lifted his hoof and the dog fled, battered and whimpering.</t932></passage>

<passage><t933>Soon the tumult ceased.</t933> <t934>The four pigs waited, trembling, with guilt written in every furrow of their faces.</t934> <t935>Napoleon demanded that they confess their crimes.</t935> <t936>They were the same four pigs who had protested when Napoleon abolished the Sunday meetings.</t936> <t937>Without further prompting, they confessed that they had been in clandestine contact with Snowball since his expulsion, collaborated with him in the destruction of the windmill, and agreed to hand over "Animal Farm" to Mr. Frederick.</t937> <t938>They added that Snowball had admitted, confidentially, that he had been Mr. Jones's secret agent for many years.</t938> <t939>When they finished their confession, the dogs, without wasting time, tore their throats out, and meanwhile, Napoleon, in a terrible voice, asked if any other animal had anything to confess.</t939></passage>

<passage><t940>The three hens, who were the ringleaders of the attempted rebellion over the eggs, stepped forward and declared that Snowball had appeared to them in dreams, urging them to disobey Napoleon's orders.</t940> <t941>They too were slaughtered.</t941> <t942>Then a goose stepped forward and confessed that it had hidden six ears of corn during the previous year's harvest and had eaten them at night.</t942> <t943>Then a sheep admitted that it had urinated in the drinking pool, instigated to do so, it said, by Snowball, and two other sheep confessed that they had murdered an old ram, very loyal to Napoleon, by chasing him around a bonfire when he was coughing.</t943> <t944>All of them were executed on the spot.</t944> <t945>And so the series of confessions and executions continued until a pile of corpses lay at Napoleon's feet and the air was heavy with the smell of blood, a smell that had been unknown since Jones's expulsion.</t945></passage>

<passage><t946>When this was over, the remaining animals, except for the pigs and the dogs, walked away together.</t946> <t947>They were shaken and dismayed.</t947> <t948>They did not know what was more terrifying: the betrayal of the animals who conspired with Snowball or the cruel repression they had just witnessed.</t948> <t949>In the past, there had been many equally terrible scenes of slaughter, but this one seemed much worse to everyone because it had happened among themselves.</t949> <t950>Since Jones had left the farm, no animal had killed another animal.</t950> <t951>Not even a rat.</t951> <t952>They reached the small hill where the half-built windmill stood and, by common agreement, they all lay down, as if huddling together for warmth: Clover, Muriel, Benjamin, the cows, the sheep, and a whole flock of geese and hens: all, indeed, except for the cat, who had suddenly disappeared shortly before Napoleon ordered the animals to assemble.</t952> <t953>For some time, no one spoke.</t953> <t954>Only Boxer remained standing, flicking his long black tail against his sides and occasionally letting out a small neigh of bewilderment.</t954> <t955>Finally, he said: "I don't understand.</t955> <t956>I would never have believed that such things could happen on our farm.</t956> <t957>It must be due to some fault of ours.</t957> <t958>The solution, as I see it, is to work harder.</t958> <t959>From now on, I will get up an hour earlier every morning."</t959></passage>

<passage><t960>And he walked away with his heavy trot towards the quarry.</t960> <t961>Once there, he gathered two cartloads of stones and pulled them to the mill before going to bed.</t961></passage>

<passage>
<t962>The animals huddled around Clover, without speaking.</t962> 
<t963>The hill where they were lying offered them a wide view across the countryside.</t963> 
<t964>Most of "Animal Farm" was in sight: the long meadow, stretching to the road, the hayfield, the drinking pool, the plowed fields where the new wheat was growing, thick and green, and the red roofs of the farm buildings, with smoke spiraling up from their chimneys.</t964> 
<t965>It was a clear spring evening.</t965> 
<t966>The grass and the blooming hedges were golden in the rays of the setting sun.</t966> 
<t967>The farm had never seemed to them—and with some surprise, they remembered that it was their own farm, and that every inch of it was their property—a place so desirable.</t967> 
<t968>As Clover looked down the hillside, her eyes filled with tears.</t968> 
<t969>If she could express her thoughts, it would have been to say that this was not what they had aspired to when they set out, years ago, to overthrow the human race.</t969> 
<t970>Those scenes of terror and slaughter were not what they had dreamed of that night when Old Major first stirred them to rebellion.</t970> 
<t971>If she herself had conceived a picture of the future, it would have been of a society of animals freed from hunger and the whip, all equal, each working according to their capacity, the strong protecting the weak, as she had protected those lost ducklings with her foreleg the night of Major's speech.</t971> 
<t972>Instead—she did not know why—they had come to a state where no one dared to say what they thought, where fierce, growling dogs roamed everywhere, and where one had to watch their comrades being torn to pieces after confessing to horrible crimes.</t972> 
<t973>There was no thought of rebellion or disobedience in her mind.</t973> 
<t974>She knew that, even as things were, they were much better off than in the days of Jones and that, above all, it was necessary to prevent the return of human beings.</t974> 
<t975>Whatever happened, she would remain loyal, work hard, follow the orders given to her, and accept Napoleon's directives.</t975> 
<t976>But even so, this was not what she and the other animals had yearned for and worked so hard for.</t976> 
<t977>It was not for this that they had built the windmill and faced Jones's bullets.</t977> 
<t978>Such were her thoughts, though she lacked the words to express them.</t978>
</passage>

<passage><t979>In the end, sensing that perhaps it would be a substitute for the words she could not find, she began to sing "Beasts of England."</t979> <t980>The other animals around her imitated her and sang it three times, melodiously, though slowly and mournfully as they had never done before.</t980></passage>

<passage><t981>They had just finished repeating it for the third time when Squealer approached, accompanied by two dogs, with the air of someone who has something important to say.</t981> <t982>He announced that by a special decree of Comrade Napoleon, the singing of "Beasts of England" had been abolished.</t982> <t983>From that moment on, it was forbidden to sing that song.</t983></passage>
<passage><t984>The animals were astonished.</t984></passage>
<passage><t985>—Why? —shouted Muriel.</t985></passage>

<passage><t986>—There is no longer any need, comrade —said Squealer dryly—.</t986> <t987>“Beasts of England” was the song of the Rebellion.</t987> <t988>But the Rebellion is now over.</t988> <t989>The execution of the traitors this afternoon was the final act.</t989> <t990>The enemy, both external and internal, has been defeated.</t990> <t991>In “Beasts of England” we expressed our longing for a better society in the future.</t991> <t992>But that society has now been established.</t992> <t993>Truly, this song no longer has a purpose.</t993></passage>

<passage><t994>Although they were scared, some of the animals would have protested, but at that moment the sheep began their usual bleating of "Four legs good, two legs bad," which lasted several minutes and ended the discussion.</t994></passage>
<passage><t995>And in this way, "Beasts of England" was heard no more.</t995> <t996>In its place, Minimus, the poet, had composed another song that began like this:</t996></passage>
<passage><t997>Animal Farm, Animal Farm,</t997></passage>
<passage><t998>You will never have any harm because of me!</t998></passage>

<passage><t999>And this was sung every Sunday morning after raising the flag.</t999> <t1000>But, for some reason, the animals felt that neither the lyrics nor the music were up to the level of "Beasts of England."</t1000></passage>
<passage><t1001>VIII</t1001></passage>

<passage><t1002>DAYS later, when the terror produced by the executions had already disappeared, some animals remembered—or believed they remembered—that the sixth commandment decreed: "No animal shall kill another animal."</t1002> <t1003>And although no one wanted to mention it in the hearing of the pigs or the dogs, there was a sense that the killings that had taken place did not agree with that.</t1003> <t1004>Clover asked Benjamin to read the sixth commandment to her, and when Benjamin, as usual, said he refused to meddle in such matters, she went in search of Muriel.</t1004> <t1005>Muriel read the Commandment to her.</t1005> <t1006>It said: "No animal shall kill another animal without cause."</t1006> <t1007>For one reason or another, the last two words had slipped from the animals' memory.</t1007> <t1008>But they confirmed that the Commandment had not been violated; because, evidently, there was ample reason to kill the traitors who had conspired with Snowball.</t1008></passage>

<passage><t1009>During this year, the animals worked even harder than the previous year.</t1009> <t1010>Rebuilding the windmill, with walls twice as thick as before, and completing it by a set date, in addition to the daily farm work, was a tremendous task.</t1010> <t1011>Sometimes it seemed to them that they worked more and did not eat better than in Jones's time.</t1011> <t1012>On Sunday mornings, Squealer, holding a long paper with one paw, would read them long lists of figures, showing that the production of all kinds of foodstuffs had increased by 200 percent, 300 percent, or 500 percent, as the case might be.</t1012> <t1013>The animals saw no reason not to believe him, especially since they could not clearly remember how things were before the Rebellion.</t1013> <t1014>Even so, they sometimes preferred to have fewer figures and more food.</t1014></passage>

<passage><t1015>All orders were issued through Squealer or any of the other pigs.</t1015> <t1016>Napoleon was not seen in public, at most, once every fortnight.</t1016> <t1017>When he did appear, he was accompanied not only by his entourage of dogs but also by a black rooster that marched ahead and acted as a sort of herald, letting out a loud crow before Napoleon spoke.</t1017> <t1018>Even in the house, it was said, Napoleon occupied quarters separate from the others.</t1018> <t1019>He ate alone, with two dogs to serve him, and always used the tableware that had been in the glass cabinet in the living room.</t1019> <t1020>It was also announced that the shotgun would be fired every year on Napoleon's birthday, just like on the other two anniversaries.</t1020></passage>

<passage><t1021>Napoleon was no longer simply mentioned as "Napoleon."</t1021> <t1022>He was always referred to ceremoniously as "our Leader, comrade Napoleon," and the pigs liked to invent titles for him such as "Father of all animals," "Terror of mankind," "Protector of the sheep flock," "Friend of the ducklings," and others of the sort.</t1022> <t1023>In his speeches, Squealer spoke with tears in his eyes about Napoleon's wisdom, the kindness of his heart, and the deep love he felt for all animals everywhere, and especially for the unfortunate beasts that still lived in ignorance and slavery on other farms.</t1023> <t1024>It had become customary to attribute every successful feat and stroke of luck to Napoleon.</t1024> <t1025>It was often heard that one hen would say to another: "Under the leadership of our Leader, comrade Napoleon, I have laid five eggs in six days," or two cows, while savoring the water from the trough, would exclaim: "Thanks to our Leader, comrade Napoleon, how delicious this water tastes!"</t1025> <t1026>The general sentiment of the farm was well expressed in a poem titled "Comrade Napoleon," written by Minimus, which went like this:</t1026></passage>
<passage><t1027>Friend of the disinherited! Source of well-being!</t1027></passage>
<passage><t1028>Lord of the feast, who ignites my soul when I gaze upon fortunate</t1028></passage>
<passage><t1029>your firm and confident gaze,</t1029></passage>
<passage><t1030>like the sun that dazzles the sky.</t1030> <t1031>Oh, Comrade Napoleon! Singular giver</t1031></passage>
<passage><t1032>of all that your creatures love</t1032></passage>
<passage><t1033>—their bellies full and clean straw to lie on—.</t1033> <t1034>All the beasts, big or small,</t1034></passage>
<passage><t1035>to sleep in peace in their stables they long for under your protective gaze.</t1035></passage>
<passage><t1036>Oh, Comrade Napoleon!</t1036></passage>

<passage><t1037>The son that luck sends me, before growing up and becoming big, and from a small and tender pup, will first learn to be faithful and devoted to you, and I am sure that this will be his first cry: Oh, Comrade Napoleon!</t1037></passage>

<passage><t1038>Napoleon approved this poem and had it inscribed on the wall of the main barn, at the opposite end of the Seven Commandments.</t1038> <t1039>Above it, there was a portrait of Napoleon, in profile, painted by Squealer with white paint.</t1039></passage>

<passage><t1040>Meanwhile, through Whymper, Napoleon was engaged in complicated negotiations with Frederick and Pilkington.</t1040> <t1041>The pile of timber was still unsold.</t1041> <t1042>Of the two, Frederick was the one most eager to obtain it, but he did not want to offer a reasonable price.</t1042> <t1043>At the same time, persistent rumors were circulating that Frederick and his men were plotting to attack "Animal Farm" and destroy the windmill, whose construction had provoked furious envy in him.</t1043> <t1044>It was known that Snowball was still lurking on Pinchfield Farm.</t1044> <t1045>In the middle of the summer, the animals were alarmed to hear that three hens had confessed to plotting, inspired by Snowball, a conspiracy to assassinate Napoleon.</t1045> <t1046>They were executed immediately, and new precautions were taken for the Leader's safety.</t1046> <t1047>Four dogs guarded his bed at night, one in each corner, and a young pig named Pinkeye was appointed to taste all his food before the Leader ate it, for fear it might be poisoned.</t1047></passage>

<passage><t1048>More or less around that time, it was disclosed that Napoleon had agreed to sell the pile of wood to Mr. Pilkington; a formal agreement was also to be celebrated for the exchange of certain products between "Animal Farm" and Foxwood.</t1048> <t1049>The relations between Napoleon and Pilkington, although conducted solely through Whymper, were almost friendly.</t1049> <t1050>The animals distrusted Pilkington, as a human being, but they much preferred him over Frederick, whom they feared and hated at the same time.</t1050> <t1051>When the summer was ending and the construction of the windmill was nearing completion, rumors of an imminent treacherous attack were increasing.</t1051> <t1052>Frederick, it was said, intended to bring against them twenty men, all armed with shotguns, and had already bribed the magistrates and the police so that, in the event he could obtain the property titles of "Animal Farm," they would not investigate.</t1052> <t1053>Moreover, some terrible stories were leaking from Pinchfield regarding the cruelties Frederick inflicted on the animals.</t1053> <t1054>He had whipped a horse to death; starved his cows, killed a dog by throwing it into an oven, and entertained himself at night with cockfights, tying pieces of razor blades to the spurs.</t1054> <t1055>The animals' blood boiled with rage when they learned of the things being done to their comrades, and sometimes they clamored to be allowed to go out and attack "Pinchfield Farm" en masse, drive out the humans, and liberate the animals.</t1055> <t1056>But Squealer advised them to avoid rash actions and to trust in Napoleon's strategy.</t1056></passage>

<passage><t1057>However, the resentment against Frederick continued to grow.</t1057> <t1058>One Sunday morning, Napoleon appeared in the barn and explained that at no time had he intended to sell the pile of wood to Frederick; he considered it incompatible with his dignity to have dealings with scoundrels of that sort.</t1058> <t1059>The pigeons, who were still being sent to spread news about the Rebellion, were forbidden to set foot in Foxwood and were also forced to abandon their previous slogan of "Death to Humanity," replacing it with "Death to Frederick."</t1059> <t1060>At the end of summer, a new plot by Snowball was uncovered.</t1060> <t1061>The wheat fields were full of weeds, and it was discovered that, during one of his nocturnal visits, Snowball had mixed thistle seeds with the wheat seeds.</t1061> <t1062>A goose, an accomplice in the plot, had confessed its guilt to Squealer and immediately committed suicide by ingesting some toxic herbs.</t1062> <t1063>The animals also learned that Snowball had never—as many of them had believed until then—received the order of "Animal Hero, First Class."</t1063> <t1064>It was simply a legend spread shortly after the "Battle of the Cowshed" by Snowball himself.</t1064> <t1065>Far from being decorated, he was censured for showing cowardice in the battle.</t1065> <t1066>Once again, some animals listened to this with some perplexity, but Squealer managed to convince them that their memories were mistaken.</t1066></passage>

<passage><t1067>In the autumn, through a tremendous and exhausting effort—because the harvest had to be done almost simultaneously—the windmill was completed.</t1067> <t1068>The machinery still needed to be installed and Whymper was still negotiating its purchase, but the construction was finished.</t1068> <t1069>Despite all the difficulties, despite the inexperience, the primitive tools, the bad luck, and the betrayal of Snowball, the work had been completed punctually on the set day!</t1069> <t1070>Very tired but proud, the animals circled around their masterpiece, which in their opinion appeared even more beautiful than when it was first erected.</t1070> <t1071>Moreover, the thickness of the walls was double what it had been before.</t1071> <t1072>Only with explosives would it be possible to bring it down this time!</t1072> <t1073>And when they remembered how they had worked, the discouragement they had overcome, and the change it would bring to their lives when the sails were turning and the dynamos were functioning, when they thought of all this, their fatigue disappeared and they jumped around the windmill, shouting triumphantly.</t1073> <t1074>Napoleon himself, accompanied by his dogs and his rooster, came to inspect the finished work; he personally congratulated the animals on their feat and announced that the windmill would be called "Napoleon Mill."</t1074></passage>

<passage><t1075>Two days later, the animals were summoned for a special meeting in the barn.</t1075> <t1076>They were stunned when Napoleon announced that he had sold the pile of wood to Frederick.</t1076> <t1077>Frederick's carts would start taking it away.</t1077> <t1078>Throughout the entire period of his apparent friendship with Pilkington, Napoleon had actually been secretly in agreement with Frederick.</t1078></passage>

<passage><t1079>All relations with Foxwood were cut off while insulting messages were sent to Pilkington.</t1079> <t1080>The pigeons were instructed to avoid "Pinchfield Farm" and to change their slogan from "Death to Frederick" to "Death to Pilkington."</t1080> <t1081>At the same time, Napoleon assured the animals that the rumors of an attack on "Animal Farm" were completely false and that the news regarding Frederick's cruelties to his animals had been greatly exaggerated.</t1081> <t1082>All those rumors had probably been spread by Snowball and his agents.</t1082> <t1083>It was now discovered that Snowball was not hiding at "Pinchfield Farm" and that, in fact, he had never been there in his life; he was residing in Foxwood —in extraordinary luxury, it was said— and apparently, he had been a protégé of Pilkington for many years.</t1083></passage>

<passage><t1084>The pigs were astonished by Napoleon's cunning.</t1084> <t1085>Through his apparent friendship with Pilkington, he forced Frederick to increase his price by twelve pounds.</t1085> <t1086>But the superiority of Napoleon's mind, said Squealer, was demonstrated by the fact that he trusted no one, not even Frederick.</t1086> <t1087>Frederick had wanted to pay for the timber with something called a check, which, it seems, was a piece of paper with the promise to pay the amount written on it.</t1087> <t1088>But Napoleon was too smart for him.</t1088> <t1089>He had demanded payment in genuine five-pound notes, which had to be paid before the timber was removed.</t1089> <t1090>Frederick paid, and the amount paid was just enough to buy the machinery needed for the windmill.</t1090></passage>

<passage><t1091>Meanwhile, the timber was being hurriedly transported.</t1091> <t1092>When it had been completely removed, another special meeting was held in the barn so that the animals could gaze upon Frederick's banknotes.</t1092></passage>

<passage><t1093>Smiling beatifically and displaying his two decorations, Napoleon lay on his straw bed on the platform, with the money beside him, carefully stacked on a porcelain kitchen plate.</t1093> <t1094>The animals slowly paraded past him and gazed at him to their heart's content.</t1094> <t1095>Boxer stretched out his nose to sniff the bills, and the thin papers moved and rustled under his breath.</t1095></passage>

<passage><t1096>Three days later, a terrible commotion was recorded.</t1096> <t1097>Whymper, extremely pale, arrived at full speed on his bicycle, threw it to the ground upon reaching the yard, and ran inside.</t1097> <t1098>Soon, a dull roar of rage was heard from Napoleon's room.</t1098> <t1099>The news of what had happened spread through the farm like wildfire.</t1099> <t1100>The banknotes were fake!</t1100> <t1101>Frederick had gotten the wood for free!</t1101></passage>

<passage><t1102>Napoleon immediately gathered all the animals and with a terrible voice decreed a death sentence for Frederick.</t1102> <t1103>When captured, he said, Frederick was to be boiled alive.</t1103> <t1104>At the same time, he warned them that after this treacherous act, the worst should be expected.</t1104> <t1105>Frederick and his people could launch their long-awaited attack at any moment.</t1105> <t1106>Sentinels were posted at all access routes to the farm.</t1106> <t1107>Additionally, four pigeons were sent to Foxwood with a conciliatory message, hoping to restore good relations with Pilkington.</t1107></passage>

<passage><t1108>The attack occurred the next morning.</t1108> <t1109>The animals were having breakfast when the lookouts came running in with the announcement that Frederick and his forces had already passed through the access gate.</t1109> <t1110>The animals boldly went out to fight, but this time they did not achieve the easy victory they had obtained in the "Battle of the Cowshed."</t1110> <t1111>There were fifteen men, with half a dozen shotguns, and they opened fire as soon as they got within fifty meters of the animals.</t1111> <t1112>The animals could not withstand the terrible explosions with their scalding pellets, and despite the efforts of Napoleon and Boxer to regroup them, they were soon driven back.</t1112> <t1113>A few of them were wounded.</t1113> <t1114>They took refuge in the farm buildings and cautiously peered through the cracks and knot holes in the wood.</t1114> <t1115>The entire large meadow, including the windmill, was in the hands of the enemy.</t1115> <t1116>For the moment, even Napoleon was at a loss for what to do.</t1116> <t1117>He paced back and forth without saying a word, his tail stiff and twitching nervously.</t1117> <t1118>They cast eager glances in the direction of Foxwood.</t1118> <t1119>If Pilkington and his people helped them, they might still come out well.</t1119> <t1120>But at that moment the four pigeons that had been sent the day before returned, one of them carrying a piece of paper from Pilkington.</t1120> <t1121>On it were written the following words in pencil: "Serves you right."</t1121></passage>

<passage><t1122>Meanwhile, Frederick and his men stopped by the mill.</t1122> <t1123>The animals watched them, and a murmur of anguish escaped their lips.</t1123> <t1124>Two of the men wielded an iron crowbar and a hammer.</t1124> <t1125>They were going to tear down the windmill.</t1125></passage>

<passage><t1126>—Impossible! —shouted Napoleon—.</t1126> <t1127>We have built the walls too thick for that.</t1127> <t1128>They won't be able to bring them down even in a week.</t1128> <t1129>Take heart, comrades!</t1129></passage>

<passage><t1130>But Benjamin was intently observing the movements of the men.</t1130> <t1131>Those handling the hammer and the iron lever were opening a hole near the base of the mill.</t1131> <t1132>Slowly, and with an almost amused air, Benjamin shook his long snout.</t1132></passage>
<passage><t1133>—I thought so —he said—.</t1133> <t1134>Don't you see what you're doing?</t1134> <t1135>They're going to fill that hole with gunpowder right away.</t1135></passage>

<passage><t1136>The animals waited terrified.</t1136> <t1137>It was impossible to venture outside the shelter of the buildings.</t1137> <t1138>After several minutes, the men were seen running in all directions.</t1138> <t1139>Then a deafening roar was heard.</t1139> <t1140>The pigeons swirled in the air and all the animals, except for Napoleon, threw themselves to the ground face down and hid their faces.</t1140> <t1141>When they got up again, a huge cloud of black smoke was floating where the windmill had been.</t1141> <t1142>Slowly the breeze carried it away.</t1142> <t1143>The windmill had ceased to exist!</t1143></passage>

<passage><t1144>Upon seeing this scene, the animals regained their courage.</t1144> <t1145>The fear and despair they felt moments before were drowned by their anger against such a vile and abominable act.</t1145> <t1146>They let out a powerful cry for vengeance, and without waiting for another order, they attacked en masse and pounced on the enemy.</t1146> <t1147>This time they paid no attention to the cruel pellets that passed over their heads like hail.</t1147> <t1148>It was a fierce and savage battle.</t1148> <t1149>The men fired again and again, and when the animals reached hand-to-hand combat, they beat them with their sticks and heavy boots.</t1149> <t1150>A cow, three sheep, and two geese died, and almost all were wounded.</t1150> <t1151>Even Napoleon, who was directing operations from the rear, was wounded on the tip of his tail by a pellet.</t1151> <t1152>But the men did not come out unscathed either.</t1152> <t1153>Three of them had their heads broken by Boxer's kicks; another was gored in the belly by a cow; one almost had his pants torn off by Jessie and Bluebell.</t1153> <t1154>And when Napoleon's nine guard dogs, whom he had ordered to circle around behind the fence, suddenly appeared on the flank barking fiercely, panic seized the men who saw the danger of being surrounded.</t1154> <t1155>Frederick shouted to his men to escape while they still could, and immediately the enemy fled cowardly and at full speed.</t1155> <t1156>The animals chased them to the end of the field and managed to give them the last kicks as they crossed the barbed wire fence at full speed.</t1156></passage>

<passage><t1157>They had won, but they were battered and bleeding.</t1157> <t1158>Slowly and limping, they returned to the farm.</t1158> <t1159>The sight of the dead comrades lying on the grass made some of them cry.</t1159> <t1160>And for a while, they stopped, disconsolate and silent, at the place where the windmill had once stood.</t1160> <t1161>Yes, it was gone; every last trace of their labor had vanished!</t1161> <t1162>Even the foundations were partially destroyed.</t1162> <t1163>And to rebuild it, they could not, this time, use the fallen stones as they had before.</t1163> <t1164>Even those had disappeared.</t1164> <t1165>The force of the explosion had hurled them hundreds of meters away.</t1165> <t1166>It was as if the windmill had never existed.</t1166></passage>

<passage><t1167>When they approached the farm, Squealer, who had been inexplicably absent during the fight, came skipping towards them, wagging his tail and brimming with joy.</t1167> <t1168>And the animals heard, coming from the farm buildings, the solemn boom of a shotgun.</t1168></passage>
<passage><t1169>—What was that shot for? —asked Boxer.</t1169></passage>
<passage><t1170>—To celebrate our victory! —shouted Squealer.</t1170></passage>

<passage><t1171>—What victory? —exclaimed Boxer.</t1171> <t1172>His knees were bleeding, he had lost a horseshoe, one hoof was cracked, and a dozen pellets were embedded in a hind leg.</t1172></passage>
<passage><t1173>—What victory, comrade?</t1173> <t1174>Haven't we driven the enemy off our soil, the sacred soil of "Animal Farm"?</t1174></passage>
<passage><t1175>—But they have destroyed the mill.</t1175> <t1176>And we have worked for two years to build it!</t1176></passage>

<passage><t1177>—What does it matter?</t1177> <t1178>We will build another windmill.</t1178> <t1179>We will build six windmills if we want.</t1179> <t1180>You do not appreciate, comrades, the importance of what we have done.</t1180> <t1181>The enemy was occupying this ground we stand on.</t1181> <t1182>And now, thanks to the leadership of Comrade Napoleon, we have recaptured every inch of it!</t1182></passage>
<passage><t1183>—So, have we regained what we had before? —asked Boxer.</t1183></passage>
<passage><t1184>—That is our victory —added Squealer.</t1184></passage>

<passage><t1185>They limped into the yard.</t1185> <t1186>The pellets, embedded in Boxer's leg, burned him painfully.</t1186> <t1187>He saw before him the heavy task of rebuilding the windmill from the foundations and, in his imagination, he prepared for the task.</t1187> <t1188>But for the first time, it occurred to him that he was eleven years old and that perhaps his great muscles were no longer what they had been before.</t1188> <t1189>But when the animals saw the green flag waving and heard the gun being fired again —seven times in total— and listened to the speech Napoleon gave, congratulating them on their conduct, it seemed to them that, after all, they had achieved a great victory.</t1189> <t1190>The dead in the battle received a solemn burial.</t1190> <t1191>Boxer and Clover pulled the cart that served as a hearse and Napoleon himself led the procession.</t1191> <t1192>For two whole days, celebrations took place.</t1192> <t1193>There were songs, speeches, and more gunfire, and a special gift of an apple was given to each animal, with two ounces of corn for each bird and three biscuits for each dog.</t1193> <t1194>It was announced that the battle would be called the Battle of the Windmill and that Napoleon had created a new decoration, the "Order of the Green Banner," which he awarded to himself.</t1194> <t1195>In the general rejoicing, the unfortunate incident of the banknotes was forgotten.</t1195></passage>

<passage><t1196>A few days later, the pigs found a case of whiskey in the basement of the house.</t1196> <t1197>It had been overlooked when the building was occupied.</t1197> <t1198>That night, loud songs were heard from the house, where, to everyone's surprise, the chords of "Beasts of England" were intermingled.</t1198> <t1199>Around half-past nine, Napoleon, wearing one of Mr. Jones's old bowler hats, was seen exiting through the back door, galloping around the yard, and re-entering.</t1199> <t1200>But, in the morning, a profound silence reigned in the house.</t1200> <t1201>Not a single pig was moving.</t1201> <t1202>It was almost nine when Squealer made his appearance, walking slowly and clumsily, his eyes dull, his tail hanging limply, and looking seriously ill.</t1202> <t1203>He gathered the animals and told them he had bad news to share.</t1203> <t1204>Comrade Napoleon was dying!</t1204></passage>

<passage><t1205>Expressions of pain rose in a unified cry.</t1205> <t1206>Straw was placed at all the entrances of the house and the animals walked on tiptoe.</t1206> <t1207>With tears in their eyes, they asked each other what they would do if they lost their Leader.</t1207> <t1208>The rumor spread that Snowball, despite everything, had managed to introduce poison into Napoleon's food.</t1208> <t1209>At eleven, Squealer came out to make another announcement.</t1209> <t1210>As his last act on earth, comrade Napoleon issued a solemn decree: the act of drinking alcohol would be punished by death.</t1210></passage>

<passage><t1211>At dusk, however, Napoleon seemed to be somewhat better and the next morning Squealer was able to tell them that he was on the way to a full recovery.</t1211> <t1212>That same night Napoleon was up and the next day it was known that he had ordered Whymper to buy some pamphlets on fermentation and distillation of beverages in Willingdon.</t1212> <t1213>A week later Napoleon ordered that the field behind the orchard be plowed, intended as a recreational area for animals retired from work.</t1213> <t1214>It was said that the field was exhausted and needed to be cultivated again, but it soon became known that Napoleon intended to sow it with barley.</t1214></passage>

<passage><t1215>More or less around that time, a strange incident occurred that almost no one was able to understand.</t1215> <t1216>One night, around twelve, a loud crash was heard in the yard, and the animals came running out.</t1216> <t1217>It was a clear, moonlit night.</t1217> <t1218>At the foot of the main barn wall, where the seven commandments were inscribed, there was a ladder broken into two pieces.</t1218> <t1219>Squealer, momentarily stunned, was lying on the ground, and very close by were a lantern, a brush, and a spilled can of white paint.</t1219> <t1220>The dogs immediately formed a circle around Squealer and escorted him back to the house as soon as he could walk.</t1220> <t1221>None of the animals could understand what it meant, except old Benjamin, who moved his snout knowingly, pretending to understand, but said nothing.</t1221></passage>

<passage><t1222>After a few days, when Muriel was reading the seven commandments, she noticed that there was another one that the animals remembered incorrectly.</t1222> <t1223>They believed that the fifth commandment said: "No animal shall drink alcohol," but they overlooked two words.</t1223> <t1224>Now the commandment indicated: "No animal shall drink alcohol to excess."</t1224></passage>
<passage><t1225>IX</t1225></passage>

<passage><t1226>Boxer's split hoof took a long time to heal.</t1226> <t1227>They had begun the reconstruction of the windmill the day after the victory celebrations ended.</t1227> <t1228>Boxer refused to take even a single day off and made it a point of honor not to show that he was in pain.</t1228> <t1229>At night, he would privately admit to Clover that his hoof bothered him a lot.</t1229> <t1230>Clover treated it with herbal poultices that she prepared by chewing them, and both she and Benjamin asked Boxer to work less.</t1230> <t1231>"A horse's lungs are not eternal," she would tell him.</t1231> <t1232>But Boxer paid no attention to her.</t1232> <t1233>He said he had only one true ambition left: to see the windmill well advanced before reaching retirement age.</t1233></passage>

<passage><t1234>In the beginning, when the laws of "Animal Farm" were formulated, the following retirement ages were set: horses and pigs at twelve years, cows at fourteen, dogs at nine, sheep at seven, and chickens and geese at five.</t1234> <t1235>Generous pensions were established for old age.</t1235> <t1236>Until then, no animal had retired, but lately, the discussion of the matter was increasing.</t1236> <t1237>Now that the small field behind the orchard had been designated for barley, there was a rumor that a corner of the long pasture would be fenced off, turning it into a field where retired animals would graze.</t1237> <t1238>For horses, it was said, the pension would be five pounds of maize per day and in winter fifteen pounds of hay, with a carrot or possibly an apple on holidays.</t1238> <t1239>Boxer was going to turn twelve at the end of the summer of the following year.</t1239></passage>

<passage><t1240>Meanwhile, life continued to be hard.</t1240> <t1241>The winter was as cold as the previous one, and food even more scarce.</t1241> <t1242>Once again, all rations were reduced, except for those of the pigs and the dogs.</t1242> <t1243>“A too rigid equality in rations,” explained Squealer, “would be contrary to the principles of Animalism.”</t1243> <t1244>In any case, he had no difficulty in demonstrating to the others that, in reality, they were not short of food, whatever the appearances might be.</t1244> <t1245>Certainly, it was necessary to make an adjustment of the rations (Squealer always referred to this as an “adjustment,” never as a “reduction”), but compared to Jones's times, the improvement was enormous.</t1245> <t1246>Reading them the figures in a shrill and rapid voice, he demonstrated in detail that they had more oats, more hay, and more turnips than they had in Jones's times; that they worked fewer hours, that the water they drank was of better quality, that they lived longer, that a greater proportion of creatures survived infancy, and that they had more straw in their stalls and fewer fleas.</t1246> <t1247>The animals believed everything he said.</t1247> <t1248>In truth, Jones, and what he represented, had almost faded from their memories.</t1248> <t1249>They knew that life was hard and harsh, that many times they were hungry and cold, and generally they were working when they were not sleeping.</t1249> <t1250>But, without a doubt, it had been worse in the old days.</t1250> <t1251>They felt happy to believe it so.</t1251> <t1252>Besides, in those days they were slaves and now they were free, and that made a big difference, as Squealer never forgot to point out to them.</t1252></passage>

<passage><t1253>There were many more mouths to feed.</t1253> <t1254>In the autumn, the four sows gave birth simultaneously, nursing a total of thirty-one piglets.</t1254> <t1255>The young pigs were spotted, and since Napoleon was the only boar on the farm, it was not difficult to guess their paternal origin.</t1255> <t1256>It was announced that later on, when bricks and wood were purchased, a school would be built in the garden.</t1256> <t1257>Meanwhile, the piglets were educated by Napoleon himself in the house's kitchen.</t1257> <t1258>They did their exercises in the garden, and were discouraged from playing with the other young animals.</t1258> <t1259>At that time, the rule was also established that when a pig and any other animal met on the path, the latter had to step aside; and likewise, that pigs of any category would have the privilege of adorning themselves with green ribbons on their tails on Sundays.</t1259></passage>

<passage><t1260>The farm had a fairly prosperous year, but they were still short of money.</t1260> <t1261>They still needed to acquire the bricks, sand, and cement necessary for the school, and it was going to be necessary to save again for the mill machinery.</t1261> <t1262>Additionally, oil was required for the lamps, candles for the house, sugar for Napoleon's table (he prohibited this for the other pigs, claiming it made them fat), and all the usual supplies like tools, nails, threads, coal, wire, iron, and biscuits for the dogs.</t1262> <t1263>A stack of hay and part of the potato harvest were sold, and the egg sale contract was increased to six hundred per week, so that year the hens barely hatched enough chicks to keep the numbers at the same level.</t1263> <t1264>Rations, reduced in December, were decreased again in February, and lanterns in the stalls were banned to save oil.</t1264> <t1265>But the pigs seemed quite comfortable and, in fact, were gaining weight.</t1265> <t1266>One afternoon, at the end of February, a warm and appetizing aroma, like the animals had never smelled before, reached the yard, carried by the breeze and coming from the little house where beer was brewed in Jones's time, a house that was located beyond the kitchen.</t1266> <t1267>Someone said it was the smell of boiling barley.</t1267> <t1268>The animals sniffed hungrily and wondered if a hot mash was being prepared for their dinner.</t1268> <t1269>But no hot mash appeared, and the following Sunday it was announced that from that moment all the barley would be reserved for the pigs.</t1269> <t1270>The field behind the orchard had already been sown with barley.</t1270> <t1271>And soon it was known that all the pigs received a ration of one pint of beer per day, and half a gallon for Napoleon himself, which was always served to him in the soup tureen from the set kept in the glass cabinet.</t1271></passage>

<passage><t1272>But although there were no shortages of hardships to endure, they were partly compensated by the fact that life had greater dignity than before.</t1272> <t1273>There were more songs, more speeches, more parades.</t1273> <t1274>Napoleon ordered that once a week something called a Spontaneous Demonstration be held, the purpose of which was to celebrate the struggles and triumphs of "Animal Farm."</t1274> <t1275>At the appointed time, the animals would abandon their tasks and march around the farm's boundaries in military formation, with the pigs at the head, followed by the horses, cows, sheep, and then the birds.</t1275> <t1276>The dogs marched on the sides and at the very front, Napoleon's black rooster.</t1276> <t1277>Boxer and Clover always carried a green flag marked with the hoof and horn and the slogan: "Long live Comrade Napoleon!"</t1277> <t1278>Then came recitals of poems composed in honor of Napoleon and a speech by Squealer giving details of the latest increases in food production, and on some occasions, a shotgun would be fired.</t1278> <t1279>The sheep were the most enthusiastic about the Spontaneous Demonstrations, and if anyone complained (as some animals did sometimes when there were no pigs or dogs around) saying that it was a waste of time and involved standing around in the open for a long time, the sheep would invariably silence them with a loud: "Four legs good, two legs bad!"</t1279> <t1280>But, in the end, the animals liked these celebrations.</t1280> <t1281>It was satisfying to remember that, after all, they were really their own masters and that all the work they did was for the common benefit.</t1281> <t1282>And so, with the songs, the parades, Squealer's lists of figures, the thunder of the shotgun, the rooster's crowing, and the waving of the flag, they could forget for a while that their bellies were almost empty.</t1282></passage>
<passage><t1283>In April, "Animal Farm" was proclaimed a Republic, and it became necessary to elect a President.</t1283></passage>

<passage><t1284>There was only one candidate: Napoleon, who was unanimously elected.</t1284> <t1285>The same day it was revealed that new documents had been discovered giving more details regarding Snowball's complicity with Jones.</t1285> <t1286>According to them, it seemed that Snowball not only tried to lose the "Battle of the Cowshed" through a stratagem, as the animals had supposed, but he was openly fighting in favor of Jones.</t1286> <t1287>In fact, it was he who led the human forces and charged into battle with the words "Long live Humanity!".</t1287> <t1288>The wounds on Snowball's back, which several animals still remembered seeing, were inflicted by Napoleon's teeth.</t1288></passage>

<passage><t1289>In the middle of summer, Moses, the raven, suddenly reappeared on the farm after an absence of several years.</t1289> <t1290>He hadn't changed at all; he still did no work and spoke the same as always about Sugar Mountain.</t1290> <t1291>He would often perch on a post, flap his black wings, and talk for hours to anyone who would listen.</t1291> <t1292>“Up there, comrades,” he would say, solemnly pointing to the sky with his long beak, “up there, just behind that dark cloud you can see, lies Sugar Mountain, that happy land where we poor animals will rest forever from our labors.”</t1292> <t1293>He even claimed to have been there on one of his high flights and to have seen the perennial fields of clover and the linseed cake and sugar lumps growing in the hedges.</t1293> <t1294>Many of the animals believed him.</t1294> <t1295>Nowadays, they reasoned, their lives were nothing but hunger and work; wasn't it right and just, then, that a better world should exist somewhere?</t1295> <t1296>One difficult thing to determine was the pigs' attitude towards Moses.</t1296> <t1297>They all disdainfully declared that his tales about Sugar Mountain were lies, yet they allowed him to stay on the farm without working, with a small ration of beer per day.</t1297></passage>

<passage><t1298>After his hoof was healed, Boxer worked harder than ever.</t1298> <t1299>Indeed, all the animals worked like slaves that year.</t1299> <t1300>Apart from the usual farm chores and the rebuilding of the windmill, there was the school for the piglets, which began in March.</t1300> <t1301>Sometimes, the long hours of work with insufficient food were hard to endure, but Boxer never wavered.</t1301> <t1302>In nothing he said or did was there any sign that his strength was no longer what it used to be.</t1302> <t1303>Only his appearance had changed a little.</t1303> <t1304>His coat was less shiny and his haunches seemed to have shrunken.</t1304> <t1305>The others said that Boxer would recover when the spring grass appeared; but spring came and Boxer did not gain weight.</t1305> <t1306>Sometimes, on the slope leading to the top of the quarry, when he strained his tense muscles under the weight of some huge stone, it seemed that nothing kept him standing except his will to continue.</t1306> <t1307>At these moments, one could guess that his lips were forming the words: "I will work harder" because he had no voice left.</t1307> <t1308>Again Clover and Benjamin warned him to take care of his health, but Boxer paid no attention.</t1308> <t1309>His twelfth birthday was approaching.</t1309> <t1310>He did not care what happened, as long as a good amount of stone had been accumulated before he retired.</t1310></passage>

<passage><t1311>One summer day, at dusk, the rumor quickly spread across the farm that something had happened to Boxer.</t1311> <t1312>He had gone alone to drag a pile of stones to the mill.</t1312> <t1313>And, indeed, the rumor was true.</t1313> <t1314>A few minutes later, two pigeons came flying in with the news: "Boxer has fallen! He is lying on his side and cannot get up!"</t1314></passage>
