<passage><t1315>Approximately half of the farm animals ran towards the hill where the windmill was.</t1315> <t1316>There lay Boxer, between the shafts of the cart, his neck stretched out, unable to lift his head.</t1316> <t1317>His eyes were glassy, and his flanks were covered in sweat.</t1317> <t1318>A trickle of blood was coming out of his mouth.</t1318> <t1319>Clover fell to her knees beside him.</t1319></passage>
<passage><t1320>—Boxer! —he shouted—, how are you?</t1320></passage>

<passage><t1321>—It's my lung —said Boxer weakly—.</t1321> <t1322>It doesn't matter.</t1322> <t1323>I believe they can finish the windmill without me.</t1323> <t1324>There is a good amount of stone accumulated.</t1324> <t1325>Anyway, I only had one more month left.</t1325> <t1326>To tell the truth, I was looking forward to retirement.</t1326> <t1327>And since Benjamin is also getting old, maybe they'll let him retire at the same time, and he could keep me company.</t1327></passage>
<passage><t1328>—We must get help immediately —demanded Clover—.</t1328> <t1329>Someone should run to inform Squealer about what has happened.</t1329></passage>

<passage><t1330>All the animals immediately ran towards the house to give the news to Squealer.</t1330> <t1331>Only Clover and Benjamin stayed, who lay down next to Boxer and, without saying a word, shooed away the flies with his long tail.</t1331> <t1332>A quarter of an hour later, Squealer appeared, alarmed and full of interest.</t1332> <t1333>He said that comrade Napoleon, greatly distressed by the misfortune that had befallen one of the farm's most loyal workers, was making arrangements to send Boxer to a hospital in Willingdon for treatment.</t1333> <t1334>The animals felt a bit uneasy upon hearing this.</t1334> <t1335>Except for Mollie and Snowball, no other animal had ever left the farm, and they did not like the idea of leaving their sick comrade in the hands of human beings.</t1335> <t1336>However, Squealer easily convinced them that the veterinarian in Willingdon could treat Boxer's case more satisfactorily than on the farm.</t1336> <t1337>And half an hour later, when Boxer recovered a little, they laboriously lifted him, and thus he managed to limp back to his stable where Clover and Benjamin had quickly prepared a very large and comfortable straw bed for him.</t1337></passage>

<passage><t1338>During the following two days, Boxer remained in his stable.</t1338> <t1339>The pigs had sent a large bottle of the pink medicine they found in the bathroom cabinet, and Clover administered it to Boxer twice a day after meals.</t1339> <t1340>In the afternoons, she stayed in the stable talking with him, while Benjamin shooed away the flies.</t1340> <t1341>Boxer stated that he did not regret what had happened.</t1341> <t1342>If he recovered, he could live for about three more years, and he thought about the peaceful days he would spend in the corner of the large meadow.</t1342> <t1343>It would be the first time he would have free time to study and improve himself.</t1343> <t1344>He intended, he said, to dedicate the rest of his life to learning the remaining twenty-two letters of the alphabet.</t1344></passage>

<passage><t1345>However, Benjamin and Clover could only be with Boxer after working hours, and at noon a van arrived to take him away.</t1345> <t1346>The animals were working under the supervision of a pig, weeding the turnips, when they were surprised to see Benjamin coming at a gallop from the house, braying with all his might.</t1346> <t1347>They had never seen Benjamin so excited; indeed, it was the first time anyone had seen him gallop.</t1347> <t1348>“Quick, quick! —he shouted—.</t1348> <t1349>Come at once! They're taking Boxer away!”</t1349> <t1350>Without waiting for orders from the pig, the animals abandoned their work and ran towards the farm buildings.</t1350> <t1351>Indeed, in the yard there was a large closed van, with signs on the sides, pulled by two horses, and a sly-looking man wearing a crushed bowler hat on the driver's seat.</t1351> <t1352>Boxer's stall was empty.</t1352></passage>
<passage><t1353>The animals crowded around the cart.</t1353></passage>
<passage><t1354>—Goodbye, Boxer! —they shouted in unison—, goodbye!</t1354></passage>

<passage><t1355>—Idiots! Idiots! —exclaimed Benjamin, jumping around them and kicking the ground with his small hooves—.</t1355> <t1356>Idiots! Don't you see what is written on the signs of that van?</t1356></passage>

<passage><t1357>That pacified the animals, and silence fell.</t1357> <t1358>Muriel began to spell out the words.</t1358> <t1359>But Benjamin pushed her aside and, in the midst of a sepulchral silence, read:</t1359></passage>

<passage><t1360>—"Alfredo Simmonds, horse slaughterer and glue manufacturer, Willingdon.</t1360> <t1361>Dealer in hides and bone meal.</t1361> <t1362>Supplies kennels."</t1362> <t1363>Don't you understand what that means? They're taking him to the knacker!</t1363></passage>

<passage><t1364>The animals let out a cry of horror.</t1364> <t1365>At that moment, the driver whipped the horses and the van left the yard at a light trot.</t1365> <t1366>All the animals followed it, shouting.</t1366> <t1367>Clover moved forward.</t1367> <t1368>The van began to pick up speed.</t1368> <t1369>Clover tried to gallop, but her heavy hooves only managed a half-gallop.</t1369></passage>
<passage><t1370>—Boxer! —she shouted—.</t1370> <t1371>Boxer! Boxer!</t1371></passage>
<passage><t1372>At that moment, as if he had heard the commotion, Boxer's face, with the white stripe on his muzzle, appeared in the rear window of the cart.</t1372></passage>
<passage><t1373>—Boxer! —shouted Clover in a terrible voice—.</t1373> <t1374>Boxer! Get out of there!</t1374> <t1375>Get out quickly! They are taking you to your death!</t1375></passage>
<passage><t1376>All the animals began to shout:</t1376></passage>

<passage><t1377>“Get out of there, Boxer, get out of there!” but the van had already picked up speed and was moving away from them.</t1377> <t1378>It was not known if Boxer understood what Clover said.</t1378> <t1379>But a moment later, his face disappeared from the window and the sound of hooves kicking was heard inside the van.</t1379> <t1380>He was trying to kick his way out.</t1380> <t1381>In earlier times, a few kicks from Boxer’s hooves would have shattered the van.</t1381> <t1382>But, unfortunately, his strength had left him; and soon the sound of hooves grew weaker and died away.</t1382> <t1383>In their desperation, the animals began to appeal to the two horses pulling the van to stop.</t1383> <t1384>“Comrades, comrades!” they shouted.</t1384> <t1385>“Don’t take your own brother to his death!”</t1385> <t1386>But the stupid beasts, too ignorant to realize what was happening, laid back their ears and quickened their trot.</t1386> <t1387>Boxer’s face did not appear at the window again.</t1387> <t1388>It was too late when someone thought to run ahead to close the gate; in an instant, the van was gone and disappeared down the road.</t1388> <t1389>Boxer was never seen again.</t1389> <t1390>Three days later, it was announced that he had died in the hospital at Willingdon, despite receiving all the care that could be given to a horse.</t1390> <t1391>Squealer announced the news to the others.</t1391> <t1392>He had been present, he said, during Boxer’s last hours.</t1392></passage>

<passage><t1393>—It was the most moving scene I have ever witnessed! —expressed Squealer, raising his paw to wipe away a tear—.</t1393> <t1394>I was by his bedside until the very last moment, and in the end, almost too weak to speak, he whispered to me that his only regret was dying before the windmill was finished.</t1394> <t1395>«Onward, comrades —he murmured—.</t1395> <t1396>Onward in the name of the Rebellion.</t1396> <t1397>Long live "Animal Farm"!</t1397> <t1398>Long live Comrade Napoleon! Napoleon is always right!»</t1398> <t1399>Those were his last words, comrades.</t1399></passage>

<passage><t1400>Here Squealer's demeanor changed suddenly.</t1400> <t1401>He remained silent for a moment, and his little eyes darted suspicious glances from side to side before continuing.</t1401> <t1402>It had come to his attention —he said— that a ridiculous and malicious rumor circulated when Boxer was taken away.</t1402> <t1403>Some animals noticed that the van that transported Boxer had the inscription: "Horse Slaughterer," and hastily concluded that this was indeed Boxer's fate.</t1403> <t1404>It was almost unbelievable, said Squealer, that an animal could be so stupid.</t1404> <t1405>Surely, he cried indignantly, wagging his tail and jumping from side to side, surely they knew their beloved Leader, comrade Napoleon, better than anyone.</t1405> <t1406>But the explanation, in truth, was very simple.</t1406> <t1407>The van had previously been owned by the knacker and had been bought by the veterinarian, who had not yet erased the previous name.</t1407> <t1408>That was how the mistake was born.</t1408></passage>

<passage><t1409>The animals were greatly relieved to hear this.</t1409> <t1410>And when Squealer continued giving them more graphic details of Boxer's deathbed, the admirable care he received, and the expensive medicines that Napoleon paid for without regard to the cost, their last doubts disappeared, and the sorrow they felt for the death of their comrade was mitigated by the idea that, at least, he had died happy.</t1410></passage>

<passage><t1411>Napoleon himself appeared at the meeting the following Sunday and delivered a brief funeral oration in Boxer's memory.</t1411> <t1412>It was not possible to bring back the remains of their mourned comrade to be buried at the Farm, but he had ordered that a large wreath made of laurel from the house garden be placed on Boxer's grave.</t1412> <t1413>And after a few days, the pigs planned to hold a commemorative banquet in his honor.</t1413> <t1414>Napoleon concluded his speech by reminding them of Boxer's two favorite mottos: "I will work harder" and "Comrade Napoleon is always right," mottos, he said, that every animal would do well to adopt for themselves.</t1414></passage>

<passage><t1415>On the appointed day for the banquet, a storekeeper's cart came from Willingdon and unloaded a large wooden crate.</t1415> <t1416>That night, the sound of boisterous singing was heard, followed by what seemed to be a violent quarrel that ended around eleven with a tremendous crash of breaking glass.</t1416> <t1417>No one moved in the house before noon the next day, and word spread that the pigs had managed to get money to buy another crate of whiskey.</t1417></passage>
<passage><t1418>X</t1418></passage>

<passage><t1419>The years passed.</t1419> <t1420>The seasons came and went; the short lives of the animals flew by.</t1420> <t1421>There came a time when no one remembered the old days before the Rebellion, except for Clover, Benjamin, Moses the raven, and a few pigs.</t1421></passage>

<passage><t1422>Muriel had died; Bluebell, Jessie, and Pincher had died.</t1422> <t1423>Jones also died; he passed away in a home for drunks in another part of the country.</t1423> <t1424>Snowball was forgotten.</t1424> <t1425>Boxer had been forgotten as well, except by the few who had known him.</t1425> <t1426>Clover was now an old and fat mare, with stiff joints and bleary eyes.</t1426> <t1427>She had reached retirement age two years ago, but in reality, no animal had retired.</t1427> <t1428>It had been a long time since anyone talked about reserving a corner of the pasture for retired animals.</t1428> <t1429>Napoleon was now a mature pig of about one hundred and fifty kilos.</t1429> <t1430>Squealer was so fat that he had difficulty seeing beyond his nose.</t1430> <t1431>Only old Benjamin was more or less the same as always, except that his muzzle was grayer and, since Boxer's death, he was more bad-tempered and taciturn than ever.</t1431></passage>

<passage><t1432>There were many more animals than before on the farm, although the increase was not as great as had been expected in the early years.</t1432> <t1433>Many animals were born for whom the Rebellion was an almost forgotten tradition, passed down verbally; and others, who had been acquired, had never heard of such a thing before their arrival.</t1433> <t1434>The farm now had three horses, in addition to Clover.</t1434> <t1435>They were impressive beasts, willing workers, and excellent comrades, but very stupid.</t1435> <t1436>None of them managed to learn the alphabet beyond the letter B.</t1436> <t1437>They accepted everything they were told about the Rebellion and the principles of Animalism, especially from Clover, whom they had an almost filial respect for; but it was doubtful that they had understood much of what was said to them.</t1437></passage>

<passage><t1438>The farm was more prosperous and better organized; it had even been expanded with two strips of land purchased from Mr. Pilkington.</t1438> <t1439>The windmill was finally completed, and the farm owned a threshing machine and a hay elevator, with several buildings also added.</t1439> <t1440>Whymper had bought himself a car.</t1440> <t1441>The windmill, however, was not used to generate electricity.</t1441> <t1442>It was used to grind corn and produced a healthy cash profit.</t1442> <t1443>The animals were working hard on the construction of another windmill; when this one was finished, it was said, dynamos would be installed.</t1443> <t1444>But the luxuries that Snowball had made the animals dream of, the stalls with electric light and hot and cold water, and the three-day week, were no longer mentioned.</t1444> <t1445>Napoleon had censured these ideas, considering them contrary to the spirit of Animalism.</t1445> <t1446>True happiness, he said, consisted of working hard and living frugally.</t1446></passage>

<passage><t1447>Somehow it seemed as though the farm had grown richer without making the animals themselves richer; except, of course, for the pigs and the dogs.</t1447> <t1448>Perhaps this was partly due to the fact that there were so many pigs and so many dogs.</t1448> <t1449>It was not that these animals did not work in their own way.</t1449> <t1450>There was, as Squealer never tired of explaining to them, an endless amount of work in the supervision and organization of the Farm.</t1450> <t1451>Much of this work had characteristics such that the other animals were too ignorant to understand it.</t1451> <t1452>For example, Squealer told them that the pigs had to make an enormous effort every day with some mysterious things called "files," "reports," "minutes," and "memoranda."</t1452> <t1453>These were long sheets of paper that had to be completely filled with writing, and then were burned in the furnace.</t1453> <t1454>This was of utmost importance for the welfare of the Farm, Squealer pointed out.</t1454> <t1455>But in any case, neither the pigs nor the dogs produced anything edible through their own labor; they were many and always had a good appetite.</t1455></passage>

<passage><t1456>As for the others, their life, as far as they knew, was what it had always been.</t1456> <t1457>They were generally hungry, slept on straw, drank from the pond, worked in the fields; in winter they suffered from the cold and in summer from the flies.</t1457> <t1458>Sometimes, the oldest among them searched their murky memories and tried to determine if in the early days of the Rebellion, when Jones's expulsion was still recent, things were better or worse than now.</t1458> <t1459>They could not remember.</t1459> <t1460>There was nothing to compare their present life with, they had nothing to go on except Squealer's lists of figures which invariably demonstrated that everything was getting better and better.</t1460> <t1461>The animals found no solution to the problem; in any case, they now had little time to ponder these things.</t1461> <t1462>Only old Benjamin claimed to remember every detail of his long life and knew that things had never been, nor could ever be, much better or much worse; hunger, oppression, and disappointment were, he said, the unalterable law of life.</t1462></passage>

<passage><t1463>And yet, the animals never abandoned their hopes.</t1463> <t1464>Moreover, they never lost, not even for an instant, their sense of honor and the privilege of being members of "Animal Farm."</t1464> <t1465>It was still the only farm in the whole county —in all of England!— owned and governed by animals.</t1465> <t1466>None, neither the youngest nor even the newcomers brought from farms ten or twenty miles away, ceased to marvel at it.</t1466> <t1467>And when they heard the gun thunder and saw the green flag waving at the top of the mast, their hearts swelled with inextinguishable pride, and the conversation always revolved around the heroic days of yore, the expulsion of Jones, the inscription of the seven commandments, the great battles in which the human invaders were defeated.</t1467> <t1468>None of the old dreams had been abandoned.</t1468> <t1469>The Republic of the animals that Major had predicted, when the green fields of England would not be trodden by human feet, was still their aspiration.</t1469> <t1470>Someday it would come; perhaps not soon, maybe not during the lifetime of the current generation of animals, but it would come.</t1470> <t1471>Even the melody of "Beasts of England" was surely hummed in secret here or there; in any case, it was a fact that all the animals on the farm knew it, though none had dared to sing it out loud.</t1471> <t1472>It might be that their lives were arduous and that not all their hopes were fulfilled; but they were aware that they were not like other animals.</t1472> <t1473>If they went hungry, it was not to feed tyrants like human beings; if they worked hard, at least they did it for themselves.</t1473> <t1474>None walked on two legs.</t1474> <t1475>None called another "master."</t1475> <t1476>All animals were equal.</t1476></passage>

<passage><t1477>One day, at the beginning of summer, Squealer ordered the sheep to follow him, and he led them to a plot of uncultivated land at the other end of the farm, covered with birch saplings.</t1477> <t1478>The sheep spent the whole day there eating leaves under Squealer's supervision.</t1478> <t1479>At dusk, he returned to the house, but since it was hot, he told the sheep to stay where they were.</t1479> <t1480>And there they remained all week, unseen by the other animals during that time.</t1480> <t1481>Squealer was with them for most of the day.</t1481> <t1482>He said he was teaching them a new song, for which isolation was necessary.</t1482></passage>

<passage><t1483>A quiet afternoon, shortly after the sheep had returned from their retreat —the animals had already finished working and were heading back towards the farm buildings—, a terrified neigh of a horse was heard from the yard.</t1483> <t1484>Alarmed, the animals stopped abruptly.</t1484> <t1485>It was Clover's voice.</t1485> <t1486>She neighed again and everyone galloped, rushing into the yard.</t1486> <t1487>Then they saw what Clover had seen.</t1487></passage>
<passage><t1488>It was a pig, walking on its hind legs.</t1488></passage>

<passage><t1489>Yes, it was Squealer.</t1489> <t1490>A bit clumsily, as if he were not entirely accustomed to holding his great bulk in that position, but with perfect balance, he was strolling around the yard.</t1490> <t1491>And shortly after, through the door of the house appeared a long line of pigs, all walking on their hind legs.</t1491> <t1492>Some did it better than others, although one or two walked a bit unsteadily, giving the impression that they would have appreciated the support of a cane, but all of them successfully completed a full turn around the yard.</t1492> <t1493>Finally, there was a tremendous barking from the dogs and a sharp crowing from the black rooster, and Napoleon himself appeared, standing majestically, casting arrogant glances from side to side with the dogs jumping around.</t1493></passage>
<passage><t1494>He was carrying a whip in his hand.</t1494></passage>

<passage><t1495>A deathly silence fell.</t1495> <t1496>Astonished, terrified, huddled together, the animals watched the long line of pigs slowly marching around the yard.</t1496> <t1497>It was as if the world had turned upside down.</t1497> <t1498>There came a moment when the first impression passed and, despite everything —despite their terror of the dogs and the habit, acquired over many years, of never complaining, never criticizing—, some word of protest was about to burst out.</t1498> <t1499>But at that precise moment, as if obeying a signal, all the sheep burst into a tremendous bleating: "Four legs good, two legs better!</t1499> <t1500>Four legs good, two legs better! Four legs good, two legs better!"</t1500></passage>

<passage><t1501>The chant continued for five minutes without stopping.</t1501> <t1502>And when the sheep fell silent, the opportunity to protest had passed, for the pigs had re-entered the house.</t1502></passage>

<passage><t1503>Benjamin felt a snout brush against his shoulder.</t1503> <t1504>He turned around.</t1504> <t1505>It was Clover.</t1505> <t1506>Her old eyes seemed dimmer than ever.</t1506> <t1507>Without saying anything, she gently tugged at his mane and led him to the end of the main barn, where the seven commandments were inscribed.</t1507> <t1508>For a minute or two, they stood looking at the tarred wall with its white letters.</t1508></passage>

<passage><t1509>—My eyesight is failing me —she finally said—.</t1509> <t1510>Not even when I was young could I read what was written there.</t1510> <t1511>But it seems to me that this wall has changed.</t1511> <t1512>Are the seven commandments the same as before, Benjamin?</t1512></passage>

<passage><t1513>For the first time, Benjamin agreed to break the custom and read what was written on the wall.</t1513> <t1514>There was nothing there except a single Commandment.</t1514> <t1515>It said:</t1515></passage>
<passage><t1516>ALL ANIMALS ARE EQUAL, BUT SOME ANIMALS ARE MORE EQUAL THAN OTHERS.</t1516></passage>

<passage><t1517>After that, it did not seem strange to them that the next day the pigs who were supervising the farm work were all carrying a whip in their hands.</t1517> <t1518>It did not seem odd to them to learn that the pigs had bought a radio, were arranging for the installation of a telephone, and had subscribed to John Bull, Tit-Bits, and the Daily Mirror.</t1518> <t1519>It did not seem strange to them when they saw Napoleon walking through the garden of the house with a pipe in his mouth; no, not even when the pigs took Mr. Jones's clothes out of the wardrobes and put them on; Napoleon appeared in a black jacket, breeches, and leather leggings, while his favorite wore the silk dress that Mrs. Jones used to wear on Sundays.</t1519></passage>

<passage><t1520>A week later, one afternoon, a number of cars arrived at the farm.</t1520> <t1521>A delegation of neighboring farmers had been invited to make a visit.</t1521> <t1522>They toured the farm and expressed great admiration for everything they saw, especially the windmill.</t1522></passage>

<passage><t1523>The animals were weeding the turnip field.</t1523> <t1524>They worked almost without lifting their faces from the ground and without knowing whom they should fear more: the pigs or the human visitors.</t1524></passage>

<passage><t1525>That night, loud laughter and songs were heard from the house.</t1525> <t1526>The sound of the mingled voices suddenly aroused the curiosity of the animals.</t1526> <t1527>What could be happening there, now that, for the first time, animals and humans were gathered on equal terms?</t1527> <t1528>By mutual agreement, they crawled in utmost silence to the garden of the house.</t1528></passage>

<passage><t1529>Upon reaching the entrance, they stopped, half scared, but Clover advanced resolutely and the others followed her.</t1529> <t1530>They tiptoed to the house, and the taller animals peered through the dining room window.</t1530> <t1531>There, around a long table, sat half a dozen farmers and half a dozen of the most eminent pigs, with Napoleon occupying the place of honor at the head.</t1531> <t1532>The pigs seemed to be completely at ease in the chairs.</t1532> <t1533>The group was playing a card game, but they had paused for a moment, undoubtedly to make a toast.</t1533> <t1534>A large jug was passing from hand to hand and the glasses were being filled with beer over and over again.</t1534></passage>

<passage><t1535>Mr. Pilkington, of Foxwood, stood up with a glass in his hand.</t1535> <t1536>In a moment, he explained, he was going to request a toast from those present.</t1536> <t1537>But first, he felt obliged to say a few words.</t1537></passage>

<passage><t1538>“It was a source of great satisfaction for him,” he said, “and he was sure that for all the attendees, to see that a long period of distrust and disagreements was coming to an end.</t1538> <t1539>There was a time, not that he, or any of those present, shared such feelings, but there was a time when the respectable owners of 'Animal Farm' were considered, he wouldn’t say with hostility, but with a certain degree of suspicion by their human neighbors.</t1539> <t1540>Unfortunate incidents occurred and misunderstandings were easy.</t1540> <t1541>It was believed that the existence of a farm owned and governed by pigs was in some way abnormal and that it could have a disturbing effect on the neighborhood.</t1541> <t1542>Too many farmers assumed, without proper information, that a spirit of debauchery and indiscipline prevailed on that farm.</t1542> <t1543>They had been worried about the consequences this would bring to their own animals or even to their human employees.</t1543> <t1544>But all these doubts were now dispelled.</t1544> <t1545>He and his friends had just visited 'Animal Farm' and inspected every inch with their own eyes.</t1545> <t1546>And what had they found?</t1546> <t1547>Not only the most modern methods, but a discipline and order that should serve as an example for farmers everywhere.</t1547> <t1548>He believed he was right in saying that the lower animals of 'Animal Farm' did more work and received less food than any animal in the county.</t1548> <t1549>Indeed, he and his visiting colleagues observed many details that they planned to implement on their farms immediately.</t1549></passage>

<passage><t1550>“I would like to conclude my speech,” he said, “by once again emphasizing the friendly sentiment that existed, and should exist, between 'Animal Farm' and its neighbors."</t1550> <t1551>There was, and should be, no clash of interests of any kind between the pigs and the human beings.</t1551> <t1552>Their efforts and their difficulties were identical.</t1552> <t1553>Wasn't the labor problem the same everywhere?”</t1553> <t1554>Here it seemed that Mr. Pilkington was about to tell some pre-prepared joke, but for a moment laughter overcame him, and he couldn't utter a word.</t1554> <t1555>After a moment of choking during which his various chins turned red, he managed to explain:</t1555></passage>
<passage><t1556>"While you have to deal with your lower animals," he said, "we have our lower classes!"</t1556></passage>

<passage><t1557>This occurrence made them burst into laughter; and Mr. Pilkington once again congratulated the pigs on the meager rations, the long working hours, and the lack of mollycoddling he observed at "Animal Farm."</t1557></passage>
<passage><t1558>"And now," he finally said, "I was going to ask those present to stand up and make sure their glasses were full."</t1558></passage>
<passage><t1559>"Gentlemen," concluded Mr. Pilkington, "gentlemen, I propose a toast: To the prosperity of 'Animal Farm!'"</t1559></passage>

<passage><t1560>There were enthusiastic cheers and a clattering of feet and hooves.</t1560> <t1561>Napoleon was so pleased that he left his place and went around the table to clink his glass with Mr. Pilkington's before emptying it.</t1561> <t1562>When the cheering ended, Napoleon, who remained standing, hinted that he too had a few words to say.</t1562></passage>

<passage><t1563>As in all his speeches, Napoleon was brief and to the point.</t1563> <t1564>“He too,” he said, “was glad that the period of disagreements had come to an end.</t1564> <t1565>For a long time, there had been rumors spread —he had good reasons to believe by some malicious enemy— that there was something subversive and even revolutionary in his and his colleagues' views.</t1565> <t1566>They were attributed the intention of fomenting rebellion among the animals of neighboring farms.</t1566> <t1567>Nothing could be further from the truth!</t1567> <t1568>Their only desire, now and in the past, was to live in peace and maintain normal relations with their neighbors.</t1568> <t1569>This farm that he had the honor to control,” he added, “was a cooperative enterprise.</t1569> <t1570>The property titles, which were in his possession, belonged to all the pigs collectively.</t1570></passage>

<passage><t1571>"He did not believe," he said, "that there were still traces of the old suspicions, but certain changes had just been introduced into the farm's routine that would have the effect of fostering, even more, mutual trust."</t1571> <t1572>Until then, the animals on the farm had the somewhat silly habit of addressing each other as "comrade."</t1572> <t1573>That was going to be abolished.</t1573> <t1574>There was also another very strange custom, whose origin was unknown: parading every Sunday morning before the skull of a pig nailed to a post in the garden.</t1574> <t1575>That was also going to be abolished, and the skull had already been buried.</t1575> <t1576>Their visitors had also observed the green flag that waved at the top of the mast.</t1576> <t1577>In that case, they surely noticed that the hoof and the white horn that were previously marked on it had been removed.</t1577> <t1578>Henceforth, it would simply be a green flag.</t1578></passage>

<passage><t1579>»I had to make only one criticism of Mr. Pilkington's magnificent and friendly speech.</t1579> <t1580>Mr. Pilkington referred throughout to "Animal Farm".</t1580> <t1581>He could not know, of course —because he, Napoleon, was going to announce it for the first time— that the name "Animal Farm" had been abolished.</t1581> <t1582>From that moment on, the farm was going to be known as "Manor Farm", which was its true and original name.</t1582></passage>

<passage><t1583>"Gentlemen," concluded Napoleon, "I am going to propose the same toast as before, but in a different way."</t1583> <t1584>Fill your glasses to the brim.</t1584> <t1585>Gentlemen, here is my toast: To the prosperity of "Manor Farm!"</t1585></passage>

<passage><t1586>The same cordial cheering as before was repeated and the glasses were emptied in one gulp.</t1586> <t1587>But to the animals, who were observing the scene from outside, it seemed that something strange was happening.</t1587> <t1588>What was it that had changed in the faces of the pigs?</t1588> <t1589>The old and dim eyes of Clover quickly and alternately passed from one face to another.</t1589> <t1590>Some had five chins, others had four, those had three.</t1590> <t1591>But what was it that seemed to be fading and transforming?</t1591> <t1592>Then, after the applause ended, the attendees picked up the cards again and continued the interrupted game, while the animals walked away in silence.</t1592></passage>

<passage><t1593>But they had not taken twenty steps when they stopped abruptly.</t1593> <t1594>A huge uproar of voices was coming from the house.</t1594> <t1595>They ran back and looked again through the window.</t1595> <t1596>Yes, a violent argument was unfolding: shouts, blows on the table, piercing and distrustful looks, furious denials.</t1596> <t1597>The origin of the conflict seemed to be that both Napoleon and Mr. Pilkington had simultaneously discovered an ace of spades each.</t1597></passage>

<passage><t1598>Twelve voices were shouting in anger, and they were all alike.</t1598> <t1599>There was no doubt about the transformation that had taken place in the pigs' faces.</t1599> <t1600>The bewildered animals looked from pig to man, and from man to pig; and again from pig to man; but it was already impossible to say which was which.</t1600></passage>
